Graphical abstract This review is about the coordination and defect design of carbon-based single atom catalysts (SACs) from active sites and carbon skeletons to nanocarbon-based SACs, characterization, and application for energy catalysis. Single atom catalysts (SACs) possessing regulated electronic structure, high atom utilization, and superior catalytic efficiency have been studied in almost all fields in recent years. Carbon-based supporting SACs are becoming popular materials because of their low cost, high electron conductivity, and controllable surface property. At the stage of catalysts preparation, the rational design of active sites is necessary for the substantial improvement of activity of catalysts. To date, the reported design strategies are mainly about synthesis mechanism and synthetic method. The level of understanding of design strategies of carbon-based single atom catalysts is requiring deep to be paved. The design strategies about manufacturing defects and coordination modulation of catalysts are presented. The design strategies are easy to carry out in the process of drawing up preparation routes. The components of carbon-based SACs can be divided into two parts: active site and carbon skeleton. In this review, the manufacture of defects and coordination modulation of two parts are introduced, respectively. The structure features and design strategies from the active sites and carbon skeletons to the overall catalysts are deeply discussed. Then, the structural design of different nano-carbon SACs is introduced systematically. The characterization of active site and carbon skeleton and the detailed mechanism of reaction process are summarized and analyzed. Next, the applications in the field of electrocatalysis for oxygen conversion and hydrogen conversion are illustrated. The relationships between the superior performance and the structure of active sites or carbon skeletons are discussed. Finally, the conclusion of this review and prospects on the abundant space for further promotion in broader fields are depicted. This review highlights the design and preparation thoughts from the parts to the whole. The detailed and systematic discussion will provide useful guidance for design of SACs for readers. Keywords Carbon materials Coordination chemistry Defective structure Energy catalysis Single atom catalysts 1 Introduction With the rapid development of industry in recent years, fossil energy is becoming increasingly scarce. At the same time, the wide utilization of fossil energy brings too much harmful gas for example CO2 and SO2, which leads to the greenhouse effect [1]. Recently, these energy and environmental problems have aroused great concern. Many countries also propose the goal of “carbon peak and carbon neutrality”. As a result, exploring tidal energy, solar energy, wind energy, nuclear energy, and so on to replace some fossil fuels or to reduce fossil fuel consumption has become the target of related power sector researchers in the last ten years. However, green energy is greatly affected by geography, season, and day and night, so energy cannot be stably input for social use. Electrochemical storage and conversion technology is widely concerned because of its low susceptibility these temporal and spatial factors, and thus provides stable and efficient energy. This technology is convenient to use with high safety [2–8]. People begin to pay more attention to take the advantage of gases existing in nature, for instance O2, CO2 as raw materials to convert chemical energy into electric energy. Some clean energy devices such as proton exchange membrane fuel cells and metal-air batteries have been extensively invented and applied [9–11]. ZABs and fuel cells have high specific capacity, large current density, high safety, and environmental friendliness. In addition, zinc resources are abundant, reducing production costs. Therefore, these devices are the most promising energy storage and conversion devices of the next generation. Their core reactions, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), usually have to face sluggish kinetics and high overpotential. Besides, the ORR with the formation of H2O2 byproduct will block active sites with dangerous consequences [12–16]. At present, the widely used Pt-based/RuO2-based catalyst system improves reaction kinetics and decreases the production of intermediates [17]. However, noble-metal catalysts face some severe problems, such as rare resources, high expense, bad durability, and easy poisoning by organics, such as methanol. The above problems seriously hinder the large-scale application of noble catalysts [18–20]. Therefore, it is necessary to explore some highly active and robust stable alternative catalysts to apply in oxygen- or hydrogen-involving electrocatalytic reactions. Single atom catalysts (SACs) possessing regulated electronic structure, high atom utilization, and superior catalytic efficiency have been studied in all fields in recent years. Compared to nanoparticles and sub-nanoparticles, single atoms possess higher atom utilization and lower reaction free energy, reducing the use of metals and improving reaction activity [21–25]. The catalysts work well in the formation of active sites and the interaction of intermediate products [26–28]. However, active sites are also unstable and easy to aggregate to nanoparticles due to their high surface energy [29]. Luckily, the bond between atom sites and substrates is stable when SACs have stable and efficient active sites. The key is designing and preparing active sites with a refined coordination environment or defect structure. Active sites can be divided into single atom sites and multiple-atom sites [30]. Supporting active sites possess ample and uniform electron distribution. This characteristic can be used to modulate electron structures to stabilize active sites, increase metal loading, and achieve special selectivity and superior performance [14,31–33]. For example, choosing high or low electronegativity elements coordinated with metal atoms [34,35], changing the strain effect of metal atoms [36–38], and adjusting the applied force of metal atoms and supports [39,40] are promising ways to regulate states and promote catalytic performance. Thus, different kinds of carbon-based SACs and modulation of active sites need to be discussed, which is favorable for guiding the design of more active SACs. This research is expected to promote the large-scale application of SACs-based battery devices. Owing to the high surface free energy of single atom, the single atom can be loaded onto the supports to form stable single atom. Nowadays, commonly used supports include graphitic carbon, hexagonal boron nitride, and metallic oxides, among others. Carbon skeleton materials exhibit the advantages of abundant sources and easy synthesis. Corresponding catalysts possess excellent activity and highly robust stability [16,41–50]. Carbon-based SACs have been considered promising materials due to their low cost, high electron conductivity, and controllable surface properties. Active sites bonded with carbon skeletons are commonly used as a fundamental structure for catalysts. In the past several years, researchers have discovered and synthesized a large number of carbon-based catalysts. Most of them demonstrate good catalytic activity and stability. However, there are few relevant reports about carbon skeletons with different structures, and the advantages of different skeleton structures in catalytic reactions are introduced. There are different types of carbon materials, such as hollow structures [51,52], core-shell structures [53,54], hierarchical porous structures [55], natural material structures [56,57], and so on. These structures exhibit unique advantages in catalytic reactions. These types of carbon materials can be classified into different dimensions of structure, such as 0 dimension-(0D) carbon nanospheres, 1demension-(1D) carbon nanotubes or carbon nanorods, 2 dimension-(2D) carbon nanosheets like graphene, 3 dimension-(3D) carbon nanocages, and other stereo structures. The preparation strategies of different dimensional nanocarbon-based SACs are introduced in a chapter. These different structures exhibit unique strength in catalytic reactions. Researchers have already adjusted the structure of carbon skeletons to enhance their performance. Among synthesized carbon-based SACs, almost every catalyst has different levels of defective structures [34,58]. From this viewpoint, defect modulation of carbon skeletons should be introduced. On the one hand, modulating the size of porous structure or the types of vacancies is a way to accelerate mass/electron transmission [59–63]. On the other hand, the position and number of edge defects also influence the electron structure to facilitate the adsorption/desorption of intermediate products onto the surface of catalysts [64,65]. The construction of defects on carbon skeletons is the most straightforward and widely used process to regulate the activity and selectivity of carbon-based SACs. In addition, the connection interaction between carbon skeletons and active sites is also vital for the promotion of catalytic activity. This review will give special emphasis to discussing the design strategies from theoretical knowledge to preparation routes. The types and modulation of active sites and carbon skeletons are introduced respectively. Then, the preparation strategies are evaluated from another viewpoint of different dimensional carbon-based SACs. The construction and modulation of carbon skeletons are very important for designing highly active sites in catalysts. Furthermore, the strengths and commonly used synthesis strategies of nanocarbon-based SACs are presented to achieve highly efficient catalysts for improving energy catalysis accordingly [66–69]. In order to confirm the configuration of SACs and study the relationship between performance improvement and structure, the systematic characterization of SACs is introduced in this review. A series of advanced characterization techniques, from active sites to carbon skeleton and then to catalytic mechanism, are used to study every part of SACs. Due to the development of spherical aberration correction technique and X-ray adsorption technique, the atom active sites have been identified by high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy. The carbon skeletons are also observed through scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The detailed mechanism of the reaction process has been investigated via density functional theory (DFT) calculation and some in-situ characterization. These synthesized catalysts have been employed in various fields of electrochemical catalytic reactions, including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [70], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [71], hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [72], hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) [73], etc. As the SACs have developed prosperously, the SACs with improving catalytic activity and stability are becoming potential catalysts applied in Zn-air batteries and fuel cells. Recent reviews mainly talk about the modulation of single atom active sites or carbon skeletons [34,74]. According to the above discussion about carbon-based single atom catalysts, the innovative development of carbon-based SACs is described in Fig. 1 . In this review, the structural features and design strategies from the active sites and carbon skeletons to the overall catalysts are deeply discussed. Then, the preparation routes and methods of nano-carbon-based SACs are introduced. The characterization of active sites and carbon skeletons and the detailed mechanism of the reaction process are explained. Next, the applications in the field of oxygen conversion and hydrogen conversion electrocatalysis and the relationship of the superior performances with the structure of active sites or carbon skeletons are illustrated. Finally, the conclusion of this review and prospects on the big room for promotion in a broad field are depicted. This review highlights the preparation thoughts from the parts to the whole. This review introduces the sorts and modulation strategies of part to entirety of carbon-based SACs. The content systematically concludes the design strategies and synthesis technology from a sole part to a whole part. This review will make the connection between theory and practice closely. All-round thoughts to design carbon-based SACs in the future can be found by the readers. 2 Sorts and modulation of active sites 2.1 Classification of active sites Classifying active sites is beneficial to design desired catalysts towards different selectivity and activity. At the same time, the classification provides broader rooms to choose proper active sites. All kinds of metal active sites including single atom sites and dual atom sites are applied at various reactions [75]. Single atom sites mean the single metal atom coordinated with non-metal elements and dual atom sites is two sorts of metal loaded on the supports. Dual atom catalysts are beneficial to increase the loading amount of metal and adjust the electronic structure of atom. The coordination environment of central metal and the interaction between two metals can be modified and the activity of catalyst can be improved. It also provides insights for researchers to explore more metal-active sites. This part is introduced depending on the type of metal in the active sites and their application in different reactions. 2.1.1 Single atom sites Single atom sites have the kind of noble metal atoms and non-noble metal atoms. Nowadays, widely used metals are Pt and Ru. However, loading noble metal on carbon supports is a difficult task. The reason is the weak interaction between metal atoms and carbon supports. This results in the metal atoms aggregating into nanoparticles. Different sorts of active sites are designed to achieve even loading of single atom sites. Pt single atom catalysts based on carbon-black with 0.09 mgPt cm−2 of low loading amounts and high utilization were synthesized by Xu et al. The corresponding active sites of Pt-pyridine nitrogen-carbon perform strong methanol/CO toxicity resistance and superior ORR activity (Fig. 2 a) [17]. Researchers synthesized Pt-S carbon-based catalysts with Pt-S4 active sites using the wet-chemistry method, and the Pt contents of catalysts reached up to 5 wt% (Fig. 2b). Due to its exceptional S coordination and specific 3D graphene carbon nanowire structure was formed through zeolite template carbon substrate [76]. Besides, although some noble metals Rh, Pd, Ir, and Ag perform high catalytic activity and long operating time, the high cost, poor stability, and weak anti-methanol toxicity ability are challenging. To reduce cost, regulated carbon supports provide more binding sites for metal ions increasing metal loading. SiO2 served as a hard template when acid or base is added to etch SiO2 spheres will get mesoporous materials of high specific surface area. At the same time, Ru and the other various noble metal catalysts were composited (Fig. 2c) [77]. Afterward, the exploration of novel metal active site catalysts is rising. Recently, researchers have found transition metals like: Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Mo, and a small main group metal like Mg present excellent catalytic performance in the field of catalysis. Among them, Fe-N x carbon-based SACs are used most widely because they perform the best performance in ORR. For example, Li and coworkers prepared Fe-N4 active sites on ZIF-derived carbon supports exhibiting a half potential of 0.900 V in 0.1 M KOH (Fig. 2d) [78]. Besides, metal Mn catalysts with MnN2C2 active sites achieved excellent bi-functionality in oxygen conversion reactions (Fig. 2e) [79]. Chen and his coworkers synthesized Co nitrogen-carbon materials on nitrogen-doped graphene oxide by cryo-pyrolysis. The hydrogen evolution reaction of H2O showed a low overpotential of 30 mV [80]. Zn+ (3d 104s 1) has a delocalized electronic structure to adsorb intermediates, facilitating a complete charge transfer from the substrate to the intermediates. The addition of Zn2+ during the reaction effectively avoided the Fenton reaction. Zn-B/N-C catalysts with excellent ORR performance under acidic and alkaline conditions were synthesized using ZnCl2, chitin, and boric acid with fewer raw materials by stirring pyrolysis. The active sites are Zn coordinated with two B atoms (green atom) and two N atoms (blue atom) (Fig. 2f) [81]. The main group elements (Mg, Al, and Ca) have a too strong connection or too weak connection with adsorbent because of the wide sp orbital and the empty p-orbital of adsorbent, thus they do not have high catalytic activity. Chen et al. adjusted the number of coordination atoms to make p-band center of Mg shift upward, and the synthesized Mg-N-C catalysts possessed a high half potential of 0.91 V in ORR (Fig. 2g and h). The density function theory calculated that when two nitrogen elements were coordinated with Mg, the reactivity was the highest [82]. In addition, some p-block metals in the main group containing Sb and Sn have also attracted attention. In 2020, Sb-N-C was synthesized by polymerization and pyrolysis of polyaniline and metal precursor. Compared with the transition metal-based catalysts synthesized by the same method, Sb-N-C catalysts have a higher catalytic activity. The metal atoms coordinated with four pyridine nitrogen were shown in Fig. 2(i) as the active sites [83]. Noble metals, non-noble metals include transition metals and main metals related active sites, different metals form a specific coordination with non-metallic elements to obtain active sites, the application of the highest activity in catalytic reactions. More types of metal elements should be developed in the future. By combining metal atoms with different kinds and order of non-metallic elements, the active single atom site with high activity is found. 2.1.2 Multiple-atom sites Adding another metal around a single metal increases the activity to a greater extent. The following operation regulates the electronic structure of the multiple-atom sites, and the multiple metals and improves the activity and versatility of the catalytic active sites [84,85]. Dual-atom sites are divided into two of the same-bimetal and two different-bimetal sites. Among the same metal, Co2N5 active sites were synthesized through a one-step pyrolysis method by Chen and his coworkers. When the Zn/Co atomic ratio was 10:1, the thermodynamically stable clusters were responsible for Co2N5 active sites existing on the surface of catalysts as shown in Fig. 3 (a). The Co2N5 dual-atom sites were also confirmed by extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and DFT. The EXAFS Fourier transformed (FT) spectra show the peak of the CoCo bond and the further FEFF-calculated k 2-weighted EXAFS depicts the CoCo path maximum to 6.79 Å−1 in Co-N-C-10 catalysts (Fig. 3b). The DFT simulated Co2N5has a bond length of 2.21 Å approaching EXAFS calculated to be 2.12 Å (Fig. 3c). Co2N5-C performed a 12 times higher ORR activity than that of single metal CoN4-C [86]. Recently, Niu and coworkers design the method of synthesizing homonuclear and heteronuclear bimetal sites. The method is obtaining the metal precursors, then adding the precursors to the ZIF-8 solution, and pyrolyzing. Metal macrocyclic compounds coated with carbon skeletons promote the formation of more bimetallic atomic sites. Furthermore, the FeCu bimetal sites perform the best activity among various bimetal sites (Fig. 3d) [87]. In two heteronuclear sites, there are non-noble metals, non-noble metals combined with noble metals, and noble metals. (Fe, Co)/N-C catalysts were synthesized with MOF and metal precursor. The construction of FeCoN6 active sites increases the bond length of the O2 molecule by combining Fe and Co with two atoms of oxygen molecule, respectively, thus facilitating the rupture of the OO bond and improving the reaction efficiency (Fig. 3e) [88]. Besides, non-noble metals and noble metals with coordination atoms are prepared. Through DFT, connected CoPt in a nitrogen-doped four-atom vacancy in graphene (CoPt@N8V4) has the optimal activity in all bi-metal theoretical models [89]. The constructed catalysts possessed high ORR activity and high selectivity for the 4e− pathway because of asymmetric electron density around Pt and Co metal center [90]. Pt-Ru attached to N doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) was synthesized by an atomic deposition method, and the active sites were determined to adsorb up to 5H, with the most stable structure and the best performance of HER [91]. Apart from the connected dual-atom sites, there are still separate dual-atom sites, such as separate Co and Fe bimetal carbon-based catalysts from TM@MET-6 energetic metal-organic frameworks (EMOFs) precursors. These precursors produced a lot of gas contributing to the dispersion of Co and Fe. The existence of isolated Fe-N4 and Co-N4 was proved via X-ray adsorption spectroscopy (XAS) in Fig. 3(f) [92]. Another isolated dual-atom site model is that two different single metal active sites are loaded on each side of the hollow sphere, a Janus hollow sphere structure. Qiu and his coworkers loaded Fe and Ni metals on two opposite planes of the support (Fig. 3g), where Fe and Ni are conducive to the ORR and OER, respectively. The prepared catalysts exhibited bifunctionality with a voltage gap of 0.79 V (E j=10 − E 1/2) and a long cycle running time of 200 h [53]. Compared with the connected dual-atom sites, separated dual-atom sites perform lower activity toward reaction. Therefore, great advance is made to create more connected dual-atom sites. In addition, a few monatomic catalysts with tri-atom sites have been reported. ZnFeCo-NC was formed using formamide to make a Schiff base reaction happen undergoing the chelated reaction of nitrogen-sites with metal ions under a low temperature of 180 °C for 12 h. The isolated atoms distribution was observed from AC-HAADDF-STEM. This formation of tri-metallic sites profits from the 1D long molecular chain, and offers many anchor sites for metal ions [93]. Multiple-atom sites include dual-atom and tri-atom sites, among which dual-atom sites are also introduced connected and separated, and the advantages of different types of multiple-atom sites in catalyzing electrochemistry reactions are described, such as facilitating the binding of reaction species and speeding up the catalytic reaction efficiency when charging or discharging. In the future, multi-atom catalysts should also develop more types of multi-atomic sites such as separate polymetallic clusters. And the development of multiple-atom sites for more metals with four or five metals to further improve electrocatalytic activity. 2.2 Modulation of the active sites Active sites are the sites where reactions occur, and the modulation of active sites directly improves the reaction activity. Single atom catalysts possess single atoms located at the various atom-doped supports, and thus it is conductive to modulate their electronic and geometric structure. Currently, the generally studied modulated thoughts are as follows: the modulation of coordination environment, the modulation of strain, and the interaction between metal atoms and carbon supports. 2.2.1 Sorts and number of coordinate element Doping coordination elements commonly include B, C, N, O, P, S, and Cl. Further, the coordination sorts are divided into mono-element coordination containing high electronegativity C, N, O, and di-element coordination captaining very high electronegativity, such as BN, NO, and CN. Besides the combination of high electronegativity with low electronegativities, such as NP, NCl, and NS, there are still a few tri-element coordination catalysts, such as NPS. The same coordination element has different number of coordination atoms on the catalytically active carbon synthesized by different precursors or from different technical routes. As a result, different coordination numbers of active sites are formed. Nitrogen is the most commonly used coordination element. When only N coordinates with metal atoms, active sites coordinated with four pyridine nitrogen atoms are usually formed [94], and there are also a few two coordination [95], three coordination [96], and five coordination active sites [97]. Take five coordination active sites for an example, Chen and his coworkers synthesized precursors UIO (bpdc) metal-organic framework with ZrCl2 dipyridine compounds as raw materials. Subsequently, five pyridine nitrogen coordination Fe metal active sites were formed by further pyrolysis and acid etching. Synthesized precursors are beneficial for metal ions coordinated with two pyridine nitrogen stabilizing Fe atoms on carbon supports (Fig. 4 a) [97]. The uniform and atomic Fe active sites can be seen in HAADF-STEM. The only Fe–N (1.43 Å) peak of Fe SAC/N-C in Fig. 4(b) manifests the isolated Fe atom formed. The fitting result of the coordination environment of five N is verified by EXAFS. The coordination geometric structure contributes to the asymmetric electronic structure (Fig. 4c). Furthermore, DFT calculation showed that the catalytic activity of the five-coordination sites was higher than that of the four-coordination nitrogen active sites. It was related to the metal of the five-coordination active sites with a lower reaction barrier of RDS than 4 pyridine N coordination active sites. This improved the transmission rate between electrons which was conducive to the conversion of oxygen radicals into OH* on the active sites, thus accelerating the ORR. In the environment of all kinds of atomic coordination, NC coordination is common [98]. Using a supramolecular self-assembly strategy and subsequent carbonization, Ag monatomic catalysts with C and N coordination were formed. On carbon nitride (CN) supports, the Ag with N4 coordination transfers an electron to CN more slowly than Ag-N2C2 coordination. Compared with the AgN4 sites formed by Ag NPs loaded on GO, the AgN2C2 active sites have higher catalytic activity. AgN2C2 sites have a more uniform and larger electron density than AgN4 through simulated charge density mapping of DFT calculation, which is conducive to electron transfer. In addition, the wave range of light is increased, thus the more excited electron accelerates the process of reaction. Another type of diatomic coordination is the addition of O atoms based on the N element, and the addition of O atoms can adjust the energy level of the Fe atoms increasing the catalytic activity. In the preparation process, resorcinol-formaldehyde resin was used to form a carbon chain and introduce an oxygen-contained radical. Besides, the addition of Zn2+ prevents the aggregation of Fe atoms (Fig. 4d). The active site is the FeN4C layer-O-FeN4C layer-OH (2L-Up) in Fig. 4(e). Between the layers, the oxygen atom can accelerate electron transfer. Besides, O with the stronger electronegativity withdraws electrons from Fe forming lower charge density to weaken the adsorption interaction between Fe and O2, thus improving the reaction rate [99]. Researchers pointed out that NP and NS coordination are more active than NB coordination by theoretical calculation [100]. Researchers used triphenylphosphine (TPP) as a phosphorus source synthesizing CoSA/NPC. The CoN3P as an active site needs smaller potential energy than CoN4 owing to its asymmetric electron distribution. Furthermore, CoN3P active sites with coordinated phosphorous atoms show a lower energy barrier than CoN4 active sites and accelerate the ORR reaction. Among P atom models of a different location, CoN4-P5 and Co/N3P-P8 are thermodynamically stable models. All these P-coordinated models are beneficial for the adsorption/desorption of oxygen radicals and reach a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.87 V [101]. The only modulation of coordination atom sorts cannot increase the activity efficiently. Therefore, some of these elements on a defective carbon support are presented. In the defective structure, the active sites formed by coordination atoms and defective supports contribute to higher activity. The group of Yang formed the divacancy FeN2-OH active sites by removing the adsorbed pyrrole nitrogen atoms through high-temperature pyrolysis. DFT showed that the formed divacancy defects adjusted the coordination environment. The geometric structure formation of a defective pyridine nitrogen coordination environment lowered the Gibbs free energy of RDS (OH*OH−) thus optimizing the reaction path of the active site [62]. Zhang et al. used the wet chemistry method and high-temperature pyrolysis method to generate S-Cu-ISA/SNC (Fig. 4f). The Cu-ZIF-8 absorbed sulfur in the process of heating and stirring. After pyrolyzing, the coordination of N and S and a porous structure were formed. The coordination of CuN3S1 changed the CuN4 symmetry geometric structure, and increased electron density which was beneficial to absorb oxygen-contained functional groups (Fig. 4g). The addition of sulfur powder promoted the formation of porous. In addition, CuN3S1 shows a lower overpotential than the synthesized second coordination shell S with Cu-N4 catalysts (Cu-ISA/SNC) in Fig. 4(h). Therefore, S-Cu-ISA/SNC with CuS1N3 active sites has a higher half-wave potential of 0.918 V [102]. Three elements of coordination have been reported by some research groups [103,104]. Xue et al. synthesized Mo@NMCNFs with Mo-O1N1C2 three coordinations by electron spinning technology. Both aberration-corrected (AC)-HAADF-STEM and extended X-ray absorption fine-structure (EXAFS) (Fig. 4i and j) showed that the formed single atom was coordinated with 2C, 1N, and 1O. This coordination model has lower Gibbs free energy compared with low C coordination number and N coordination (Fig. 4k). The projected densities of state (PDOS) of the Mo d band of MoC2NOH active sites are closer to the Fermi level than other coordination sites, while the Mo d-band center of Mo2C overlaps least with the Fermi level implying the MoC bonds unstable. Thus, MoC2N-OH SACs possess the best activity and stability among all the coordination types. In addition, the special structural geometry of CNFs multi-channels with cavities contributes to mass/electron transmission. The Mo@NMCNFs exhibited a lower overpotential of 66 mV at 10 mA cm−2 than commercial catalyst Pt/C in the performance of 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte [104]. The above content introduces the change of coordination number of an element, the combination of two different types of elements and the combination of different types of elements with defect structures, and the coordination of appropriate elements of three elements to obtain the catalyst with excellent performance. Obviously, changing the coordination element is a simple and effective method. However, it is also necessary to combine other adjustment strategies to improve the electrocatalytic activity. 2.2.2 Modification of strain Strain includes stretch and compresses. Strain is changing the height of the d-band center and adjusting the adsorption force of intermediate products. Recently, the strain effect has been an efficient tool to improve catalytic efficiency. The modification of strain has the potential to modulate active sites. Many factors can change the strain effect, such as support structure shape [105,106], doped atomic species [107], intra-crystalline deformation [108], and so on [109]. Wu et al. altered the structure of support surface, which compresses the strain of Fe-N. Using D-glutamic to synthesize N-stearoyl-D-glutamic acid template, and after pyrrole polymerization, the synthesized D-Fe SAC has a right-handed helical morphology. At the same time, they also synthesized LD-Fe SAC as a comparison. In the ORR test, D-Fe SAC showed a more positive E 1/2 than LD-Fe SAC in Fig. 5 (a). Through charge density difference diagram, it demonstrated a curved structure on the surface of D-Fe SAC possessing more Bader charge (Fig. 5b). Through DFT calculations, the curved Fe-N4 has a lower d-band center than planar Fe-N4 (Fig. 5c and d). The calculation results could reveal that curved Fe-N4 compresses strain, thus promoting ORR performance [105]. Different atoms have different electron densities to make bond lengths various. Through tuning the lattice size, thereby changing the d-band center energy. Amal et al. introduce phosphorus to a Pt-based catalyst. The NPC supports are formed by polymerization with dopamine monomers and phytic acid. Then, Pt single atom is immobilized into carbon precursors under impregnation. Lastly, the Pt active sites are synthesized after pyrolysis and appropriate leaching. After theoretical simulations, PtN3-PO sites with 2OH groups (Fig. 5e) among all models offered the best ORR performance (Fig. 5f). In DFT calculations in Fig. 5(g and h), the d-band center of PtN3-PO compared with PtN3 moved to the left, thus weakening oxygen-contained radical adsorption. The introduction of P provides electrons to C because of the smaller electronegativity than C. The formed stretch strain resulted in a downward shift of the d-band center [107]. Intracrystalline deformation means that one part of a crystal relative to another part of the crystal moves along a certain plane and direction. Different Fe-N4 coordination structures formed by the different temperatures are demonstrated in Fig. 5(i). The ZIF-derived nitrogen-doped carbon is prepared by carbonizing at 1100 °C firstly. Then, at room temperature, Fe3+ ions are adsorbed on or into ZIF-NC. Afterwards, at 400 °C, ZIF-NC-nFe3+ form a planar plane structure. But at 700 °C, it turned off-plane structure. The off-plane Fe-N4 SACs showed a higher half-wave potential than in-plane Fe-N4 SACs (Fig. 5j). The geometric structure in Fig. 5(k) explained the off-plane Fe-N4 shortened bond length, and this contraction strain made the up-shift of the d-band center from Fig. 5(l) of DOS. It facilitated the adsorption of O2 and promoted an excellent reaction pathway to a 4e− transfer path [108]. 2.2.3 Interaction between metal and support Metal-support interactions (MSIs) can be depicted with a d-band center or charge density and the bond length between metal and supports [110–112]. The modulation of MSIs helps to stabilize metal atoms and activate reactants, thus regulating the activity and ability of SACs. MSIs are neither too strong to keep atoms catalytically active nor too weak to avoid atoms aggregation. Many design strategies including coordination between metal and doped atoms, defect drive, and so on have been proposed to optimize the geometric and electronic structure of SACs. Metal precursors and coordination compounds react producing active sites, and determining the coordination environment. In heterogeneous catalysis, the utilization of atoms is usually low because of their low contact area with the reactant. Therefore, choosing proper metal precursors and manufacturing defects on graphene are crucial for increasing the surface area and metal atom anchoring on supports steadily. Ni precursors (NiCl2·6H2O), H2O2, and Graphene oxide (GO) were firstly added through hydrothermal reaction. The aerogel then was pyrolyzed under high temperatures with a flow of Ar (100 sccm) and NH3 (50 sccm) (Fig. 6 a). The porous structures were produced by the oxidization etching of H2O2 in a hydrothermal process. Besides, the Ni ions were absorbed on the hole-supports tightly. At the same time, MN4C4 coordination active sites with divacancy identified by XAS and STEM imaging stabilized metal ions structure imply the stable supports are unchanged after pyrolysis. The EXAFS of simulated divacancy-based MN4C4 is similar to the experimental catalyst. The catalytically active carbon is beneficial to absorb metal ions and the divacancy MN4C4 active sites exhibited high activity and stability. The relevant DFT calculations explain the OOH* intermediates linked with metal and C around N. The simulation benefits OO bond to break [113]. Between the metal atoms and supports, there is strong interaction influencing the electronic and geometric properties of Ni active sites. Thus, active surface and quick electron transfer facilitate high activity. A defect drive is also an efficient method to control MSIs. There are many different defect sorts containing edge defects, vacancy, and pores [114–116]. These defects change the charge redistribution of active sites and play an important role in improving the catalytic property. Wu and his coworkers designed a surface defect on nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) supports to capture Cu ions. The N-vacancy on ZIF-8 was firstly made by the evaporation of Zn ions by pyrolysis. Then the reduction of gas-transport Cu2O also generated vacancies in high-temperature pyrolysis at 1000 °C (Fig. 6d). The vacancies were confirmed by room temperature electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) in Fig. 6(e). The vacancies around Cu-N3 coordination increase electron density. The free energy diagram for ORR process of Cu-N3-C and Cu-N3-V models indicated Cu-N3-V possessed lower overpotential of oxygen adsorption (Fig. 6f) [114]. Ni SACs with Ni loading as high as 1.24 wt% have been synthesized by employing defect-rich graphene with abundant graphene vacancies as the support. The analysis of X-ray adsorption near edge structure (XANES) identified two defect sites and a perfect plane through the overlay of various carbon bases coincided with the experimental results. Further, the results confirmed that Ni in the defect sites possessed higher state depletion than perfect sites resulting in the strong EMSIs in Fig. 7 (a). The trapped Ni atom bonded to seven adjacent carbon atoms contributed by the two five-ring and two seven-ring carbon (D5775) is favor of HER and di-vacancy is favor of OER. Theoretical calculations demonstrate that the D5775 vacancy promotes the upshift of the d-band center to the Fermi-level enhancing the interaction with H+ and the vacancy has a strong link between the substrate and intermediate through DFT (Fig. 7b and c). Furthermore, this result illustrates that the defect caused by the chemical annealing process modulates the interactions between metal and supports [117]. Tuning the electronic structure via coordination atom was also widely applied on catalytically active carbon. In the case of doping thiophene-S next to the Fe-N4 coordination on a carbon support, it tunes the bond length of Fe-N (1.86, 1.97 Å) and enhances ORR performance, as schematically shown in Fig. 7(d). The highest ORR activity was achieved by the Fe-ISA/SNC sample with 0.896 V in 0.1 M KOH (Fig. 7e). This phenomenon was because the thiophene S supplies electrons to nitrogen and increases Fe–N bond length, and thereby it lowered the metal support interactions. The intermediate desorption energy was lowered and optimized the ORR pathway, revealed by the DFT calculations (Fig. 7f) [118]. 2.3 Summary of design of active sites The types of active sites described in this chapter can provide us with the choice of metal types when designing catalysts. Different types of active sites were obtained according to the types and number of elements and different position relationships. Only when the metal element forms a specific coordination type can it obtain a highly active catalyst. The modulation of the active site is crucial to the design of the catalyst. The active site is mainly modulated by the change of coordination elements, the strain and the interaction between metals and supports. Among them, coordination elements are formed by different types and number of single, double and triple elements. Changing the surface structure of the catalyst, choosing different types of metal precursors and coordination of different defect structures can adjust the strain and the interaction between metal and support, so as to accelerate the adsorption and desorption of reactive substances and active sites. The variety of active sites and related modulation strategies are still not enough, Future catalysts should develop more types of metal elements, and explore different coordination types, such as the formation of a variety of different metal clusters, to expand the types of active sites. At present, the above modulation method is widely used; however, these methods can only provide partial active sites. And the combination of different methods is still less studied. Therefore, different modulation methods will be combined to improve catalytic efficiency further in the future. 3 Sorts and modulation of carbon skeletons 3.1 Construction of carbon skeletons Nowadays, extensive materials have been used as host supports, such as carbon-based materials, metallic compound, and so on. Owing to their abundant defect, big surface area, and plenty of transport channels for reactant, electrolyte, and electrode, carbon-based materials are applied for all kinds of electrocatalysis fields. The widely known carbon skeletons have hollow structures, core-shell structures and hierarchically porous structures. The hollow structure has high permeability and large specific surface area. Core-shell structure has local confinement effect, which is beneficial to disperse single metal atoms. The hierarchically porous structure is easy to adjust the size of nanosheets, is conducive to the transport of substances and the load of the active site. The following section introduces different structure performing unique advantage in various catalytic reactions. 3.1.1 Hollow structure A sufficient hollow structure has an open three-dimensional architecture having enough stability. It is good for reaction species transportation. Besides, it has a high specific surface area and can expose abundant active sites. These advantages contribute to hollow structure catalysts having superior performance. However, there are few reports about thoughts of design, several sorts of carbon skeletons were introduced as follows. Maximally exposing active sites on nanosheets and shorting the distance of mass transport are still challenge in preparing carbon-based SACs. The hollow structure is formed by the template and coating layer mainly. Xu and coworkers combined ultrathin nanosheets and 3D hollow nanoboxes to improve their catalytic performance. SiO2 normally is used to be a template, and HF or NaOH is used for washing the template [59,87]. Beyond that, Fe2O3 is formed by the hydrothermal reaction and can be as a template precursor, and then the Fe2O3 is coated Mo-polydopamine on hybrid nanosheets. After calcination, the template was washed by impregnation of 6 M HCl. Afterward, hollow nanocubes with a wall of approximately 80 nm came into being. In the meanwhile, nitrogen atoms were trapped during the pyrolysis process. (Fig. 8 a). The synthesis SA-Mo-C nano boxes are staked by hierarchical nanosheets. Through TEM in Fig. 8(b), a bright hollow interior and dark flake external were observed. The AC-HAADF-STEM image in Fig. 8(c) reveals atom sites of isolated distribution via yellow circles. Many active sites were distributed uniformly through elemental mapping images, and this contributed to high ORR activity. The Tafel slope and E 1/2 of SA-Mo-C nanoboxes are better than commercial Pt/C. It explained that hollow structure absorbed O2 easily and transferred electrons quickly (Fig. 8d). Accelerated durability tests (ADTs) and chronoamperometry measurements in Fig. 8(e) showed a 1 mV decline after 5000 cycles and <3% current loss after 20 h of testing, displaying hollow structure possessing good durability. These characters contribute to the catalyst being a potential air-cathode in ZABs [119]. Recently, Shen et al. synthesized Fe-N4 active sites encapsulated in a hollow mesoporous carbon microsphere by in situ template method. This method does not need to wash the template with strong acid or base, which protects the complete structure of the catalyst. The details of the synthesis path are shown in Fig. 8(f). Firstly, zinc acetate and oxidized asphaltene (ASP(O)) were added to ethylene glycol forming ZnO template after hydrothermal treatment. Upon calcinating, ZnO nanospheres acted as templates and were infiltrated by ASP(O) forming ZnO/C composition. As reported, iron (II) phthalocyanine (Fe(pc)2) and carbonized samples (CS-600) were ground in a motor to disperse Fe active sites. Fig. 8(g) shows the hollow nanospheres with a diameter of 0.72 μm. In Fig. 8(h), AC-HAADF-STEM displayed a uniform isolated element dispersion of Fe, N, and C on FeN/CS-1000, testifying the stable 3D hollow porous structure prevents Fe NPs from aggregating. Meanwhile, wet-ball milling also benefits the dispersion of FePC. Plenty of Fe-N4 active sites greatly enhance O2 adsorption and FeN/CS-1000 is the catalyst assembled in ZABs for using in mini-electron devices such as hearing-aid (Fig. 8i). The particular mesoporous hollow structure of FeN/CS-1000 not only avoids aggregation of metal particles but also maintains the seriality of the electron/mass transfer channel during the ORR process, which greatly improves the voltaic efficiency and implies a great application potential in rechargeable battery [120]. MOFs were used to construct hollow carbon skeletons. In the process of synthesis, dopamine hydrochloride (DH) was added to contribute to the formation of the hollow carbon cavities. Simultaneously, the addition of Zn2+ vaporizing at high temperature was further beneficial for forming this structure. The big and rough surface with micropores and mesoporous is loaded with a large number of active sites and speeds up the adsorption of reactants and removal of products [121]. 3.1.2 Core-shell structure Core-shell structures of carbon-based SACs are made of metal core and carbon shell. The synthesis method is metal atoms in the metal core diffusing into a carbon shell. This unique structure keeps metal atoms from aggregating and reduces metal losses in the forming process of SACs. The catalysts with core-shell structure speed up reaction kinetics. F127 has been a soft template used for synthesizing core-shell catalysts and does not need extra steps to remove when catalysts are attained [122–125]. The added 3-Aminophenol (3-AP) and Hexamethylentetramine (HMT) resulted in carbon polymer-coated F127. The formed oligomer with Pd ions came into being core and the superpolymer was as shell in the hydrothermal and stirring process. The preliminary core-shell polymer Pd-NCs@NMPS formed in the hydrothermal method. During the process of pyrolysis, the template F127 was removed, thus a great number of uniform mesopores formed in the outer layers. In addition, metal atoms Pd from the metal core migrated to defect sites of nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon nanosphere (NMCS) in Fig. 9 (a). From the TEM (Fig. 9b and c) images, the bright sphere structure of Pd1/NMCS (Fig. 9c) was derived from the core-shell structure of Pd-NCs@NMPS (Fig. 9b). The core-shell structure in Fig. 9(b) shows that the bright center is a high atom-density core and the dark edge is a low atom-density shell. The isolated Pd atoms dispersed uniformly on the NMCS demonstrate the Pd single atoms transferring from core to shell structure (Fig. 9d). Metal atoms loading amounts reached up to 1.0 wt% because the core-shell structure confined the metal atoms migrating. After the BET test, the micropores and mesopores were verified to exist and the surface area reached up to 595 m2 g−1 owing to the addition of F127 [122]. 1, 3, 5-trimethyl benzene (TMB) could be a mediated molecular strengthening F127 and CNTs interact with each other [126]. The similar catalyst synthesized without adding TMB shows lower ORR potential than catalysts adding TMB. Core-shell single atom electrocatalysts (SAECs) with MOFs assist in performing a fast electron transfer process and high durability as well [124]. The catalysts proceed with the exothermic process in the ORR through DFT. Firstly, Co/Zn ZIF was synthesized with the traditional method, and it was deeded as a seed-coated ZIF-67 shell. After pyrolysis of different temperatures, different coordination environments Co-SACs formed (Fig. 9e). The synthesized core-shell structure of Co-N3C1-SAC was first observed by TEM (Fig. 9f). Co Single atom active sites were mainly distributed at the inner core and the outer shell regions were CNTs made up of graphitic walls via STEM-ADF. This uniform distribution is beneficial to accelerate the ORR process. The reason why active sites do not distribute at graphitic walls is that the graphitic carbon confine the movement of Co SA. This confinement is conducive to improving the content of Co atoms up to 2.1 wt%. CNTs have outstanding electrical conductivity and abundant channels, efficient electron transport, and mass transfer. DFT calculations suggest that the lower energy barriers of OOH* formation are the rate-determination step of ORR in Co-N3C1-SAC-assembled batteries than other CoNC coordination, which augments the internal activity of such cells. Co-N3C1@GC with core-shell structure possesses higher ORR half-wave potential than normal MOFs-based Co-N3C1, implying that core-shell structure enhances ORR activity (Fig. 9g) [126]. 3.1.3 Hierarchically porous structure A hierarchically porous structure can enhance mass transport and increase the number of active site amounts. Usually, this structure is synthesized by the template method [127,128] and the self-assembled method [87,129]. Single atoms are easy to aggregate, therefore, it is difficult to keep a single atom meanwhile to increase atom loading in the process of fabrication. SiO2 nanospheres possess hierarchical porous layers, and act as a template to form a hierarchical porous structure. At the same time, the pore in the SiO2 template can confine precursors to form single atoms. Chen et al. have designed a hierarchical porous single atomic Fe/N-S-doped carbon nanospheres (FeN x /NC-S) catalyst based on hierarchical porous silica nanospheres (NKM-5) template as shown in Fig. 10 (a). A template was synthesized by the hydrothermal-pyrolysis method using some big molecular precursors. The NKM-5 and thiourea were then added to the phenanthroline and ferrous sulfate solution heated at 60 °C. The phenanthroline was introduced to provide an N atom and coordinated with Fe to form a corresponding complex. This complex and thiourea mixture precursor formed hierarchical pores on NKM-5 through capillary force. After adding HF acid, the uniform Fe-N4 sites were formed on the surface of nanospheres. When NKM-5 was not added, there would not be hierarchical porous nanospheres and would emerge FeS nanoparticles. Besides, the addition of the NKM-5 templates in the formation process of carbon skeletons forms the nanospheres with an average diameter of 200–600 nm. In addition, subsequent FeN x /NC-S in Fig. 10(b) has hierarchical porous sphere-like shapes comparable to those of NMK-5 template, and with no visible metal aggregation. The AC HAADF-STEM image of FeN x /NC-S clearly showed C substrates with ample pores and no crystalline Fe compounds. Through the BET test, there is the coexistence of micropores and mesopores. By maintaining their hierarchical porous sphere-like shapes over synthesis, FeN x /NC-S kept fast ORR diffusion kinetics (∼4e− transfer pathway, current density = 10.2 mA cm−2 at 0.9 V, Tafel slope = 61.3 mV dec−1) between active Fe centers and both electrochemical reactants and products. Such carbonized substrates favored heteroatom doping and accommodated more defects, developing abundant Fe-N4-S active sites. These defects not only tuned localized C electronic structure to incur OO bond breaking but also increased substrate electrochemical active specific surface area towards enhancing ORR performance (half-wave potential, E 1/2 equals 0.92 V) in Fig. 10(c). It displayed better ORR activity than FeS/SNC (the sample prepared by direct pyrolysis without NKM-5 template). This signified the influence of mesopores. Meanwhile, this catalyst performed excellent activity well in ZABs with 0.62 V of ΔΕ. Overall, previously described structure features encompassing sphere-like 0D morphology, hierarchically assembled supportive NS pores, high substrate active specific surface area, and both uniformly dispersed Fe and N, S were responsible for the strong performance of FeN x /NC-S [130]. Furthermore, these hierarchical porous architectures prevent pores from collapsing and hinder Fe from aggregation, yielding atomic Fe-N4-S moieties during carbonization. MOFs are regarded as a template for synthesizing hierarchical porous carbon-based SACs because of their amounts of nanoscaled cavities and multiple channels [131]. However, the pores in MOFs are mainly micropores. This section introduces a novel strategy to get macropores and mesopores. Xu et al first used energetic MOFs (EMOFs) to fabricate CoFe@C catalysts with a hierarchical porosity and atomically dispersed metal sites (ADMSs) (Fig. 10d) [92]. ZnCl2 and triazole reacted to produce EMOF (MET-6), and then it absorbed Fe or Co metal ions. Only after one-step pyrolysis, the hierarchical porous carbon networks were formed. During high-temperature pyrolysis at 1100 °C, triazole was a forming agent promoting the generation of interconnected channels and hierarchical pores as Fig. 10(e). Similarly, Zn2+ in EMOFs affects hierarchical porous morphologies because of the relatively low boiling point of Zn (907 °C), thus Zn evaporation throughout pyrolysis produces porous networks. Upon sufficient Zn evaporation, all size nanopores in channels came into being. Macropores and mesopores can be investigated in TEM and micropores were tested through Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) or t-Plot methods via N2-sorption. The hysteresis loop of CoFe@C manifests the existence of micropores and mesopores. The precursors were then carbonated at 700, 800, and 900 °C. The similar structure of 800 and 900 °C products to 1000 °C indicated that the hierarchical porous carbon networks were formulated above 700 °C. The formative large carbon networks with hierarchical pores facilitate reactants and products transferring and loading more metal sites, hence, improving ORR activity. Besides, the structure provides ample surface area to anchor ADMSs to avoid metal nanoparticles aggregating seen in the AC-HAADF-STEM Fig. 10(f). Some biomass materials such as plants [132] and animals [133] possess hierarchical porous carbon networks with interconnected microchannels and various pores. They as carbon supports are used to synthesize carbon-base catalysts. For example, the paulownia wood was activated by NaOH and Na2SO3 alkaline solution at 60 °C for 5 h, then, processed free-drying obtaining activated wood substrates (AWSs). Activated carbon substrates (ACSs) were obtained by the pyrolysis process of AWSs. The catalytically activated carbon is used to synthesize Co-SACs performing excellent ORR activity. This design reduces the cost and is easy to provide ideal reaction pathway. 3.2 Modulation of carbon skeletons 3.2.1 Modulation of vacancy in carbon skeletons Among the nanocarbon skeletons, almost all structure has edge defects or vacancy defects. The research on defective structure is of especially importance for catalytic activity. The defects in the carbon skeletons affect the distribution of electron structure, thus increasing the binding rate between metal sites and carbon supports. In some research, the construction of defect in carbon skeletons can catalyze the electrochemical reaction. Besides, the defect modulation of the carbon skeletons added with the modulation of active sites will enhance the catalytic performance efficiently in reaction. Vacancy structure means that the whole carbon ring lacks several atoms. Vacancy structure breaks the symmetry of the electron structure and increases the surface charge and electron density, which is beneficial to absorb metal ions and oxygen-contained intermediates. Nowadays, Pt owing to the rare contents has limited the development of the cell. Carbon-supported divacancy-anchored platinum single atom electrocatalysts (Pt1.1/BPdefect) were obtained through H2O2 reduction treatment and subsequent pyrolysis by Xu and coworkers. The divacancies not only increase the loading of metal but also stabilize a single atom. Through XAFS characterization, proving the real active site of the reaction is Pt-C4 around the carbon divacancy to improve the reaction performance of ORR. Fig. 11 (a and b) shows that there are more single atom sites with vacancy than without vacancy in TEM. The DFT (Fig. 11c) simulated the graphene vacancy model, no vacancy, one vacancy, and two vacancy models, in which two vacancies had lower adsorption energy, and further theoretical calculation showed that the two vacancies had smaller overpotential (Fig. 11d). Pt1.1/BP defect shows excellent ORR performance in H2/O2 fuel cells, as well as high Pt content [134]. Some vacancies are made of the removal of various doped elements. The obtained supports with kinds of vacancy have been explored by rational design and precise control, such as N-vacancy [62], O-vacancy [115], S-vacancy [135], and some metal ions vacancy [136]. Liu and coworkers pyrolyzed precursors under 1050 °C of high temperature resulting in the formation of N-vacancy with N decomposing (Fig. 11e). The formed N-vacancy can coordinate with more Fe ions, thus increasing the amounts of active sites. In addition, through DFT calculation, it is demonstrated that Fe coordinated with 2 pyrrole N and an OH* is truly active sites and N-vacancy weakened the strong binding of OH* intermediate (Fig. 11f). They all respond to the enhanced ORR activity of Fe-ND/C [62]. Zhang and coworkers used the H2O2 reduction method on MoS2 to reduce sulfur ions to sulfur elemental substances, thus sulfur atoms leave and form vacancies. The exposure of more Mo active sites and delocalized electron structure formed by vacancies promote electron transfer and thus accelerate HER rate [135]. Yao and coworkers synthesized edge and central divacancy defects through two-step pyrolysis process and acid etching method in Fig. 11(g) [62]. With the increase of Fe contents, divacancies are forming and the divacancies reach the highest when the contents of Fe are 60 mg. Through AC HAADF-STEM analysis, the nanoparticles existed before acid etching and formed a mesoporous structure after etching. In EXAFS tests, the results showed that the amounts of Fe–N were more than that of Fe–Fe, further demonstrating that Fe existed in the form of a single atom (Fig. 11h). Edge-N-modified divacancies Fe catalysts (e-ND-Fe) showed higher ORR reaction performance than center-N-modified divacancies Fe catalysts (c-ND-Fe) (Fig. 11i). The orbital electron density distribution shows the e-ND-Fe with a higher electron density than c-ND-Fe. Besides, e-ND-Fe catalysts possess a narrower highest-occupied molecular orbital (HOMO)-lowest-unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy gap (0.06 eV) compared with c-ND-Fe (0.18 eV) (Fig. 11j and k). The higher electron density and narrower HOMO-LUMO energy gap both contribute to fast electron transfer and lower reaction potential energy benefiting to process of reaction. The various vacancies are still needed to be found and to be explored to improve performance. 3.2.2 Modulation of pore in carbon skeletons The pore structure means that there are a large number of atoms missing on the catalytically active carbon, containing micropores, mesoporous, and macroporous structures. The loss and reconstruction of atoms produce a large number of suspended bonds that destroy the local density of the Π electron, improving chemical reactivity [137]. The carbon skeletons are the core structure of the catalyst, which facilitates the transport of substances and electrons in the catalytic reaction. A large number of pore structures can not only rapidly transport substances and electrons, but also increase the specific surface area and the exposure of active sites, thus speeding up the reaction rate. Template etching method is usually used to make the porous structure, Wang and coworkers synthesized a SiO2 template with tetraethyl orthosilicate (TESO) as raw material, and then etched it with HF acid to form a microporous and mesoporous spherical structure (Fig. 12 a). This mesoporous structure plays an important role in promoting mass/charge transport as well as raising the utilization efficiency of Cu+ sites by improving the accessibility to the interior active sites [138]. There are also other templates to make pores, such as F127. Using vitamin B12 as the carbon source, a phenol as the binder, silica colloidal crystal (opal), and F127 as the macroporous template and mesoporous template, F127 ran out of silica opal during pyrolysis, forming mesoporous that ordered pore-like structure in closely connected macroporous bulbs (Fig. 12b). The ordered macropores and mesopores with well-defined carbon walls can be shown by TEM in Fig. 12(c) [139]. In addition to etching the template with HF acid, Zn2+ can be added to create more pore structures. For example, Lin and coworkers developed a high-efficiency method to increase porous nano-structures to modify the surface area of single atom nano-catalysts by introducing the ZnCl2 to coat on SiO2 core as shown in Fig. 12(d) [95]. Zn2+ was released during the pyrolysis process, which promoted the formation of pores. Through experimental tests, the specific surface area of the prepared catalyst marked as Fe-N-C-900 increased compared with that without ZnCl2 Fe-N-C-900-C (Fig. 12e). The porous structures are mainly micropores and mesopores through hysteresis loops. The as-synthesized Fe-N-C-900 catalyst shows a better ORR performance with the half-wave potential (E 1/2, 0.927 V vs. RHE) in comparison with Fe-N-C-900-C (E 1/2, 0.905 V vs. RHE). The high electrocatalytic performance is attributed to the hierarchical porous structure of support, as well as the FeN2 active sites (Fig. 12f). Zn2+ can produce a hierarchical structure during the reaction, which is conducive to the transmission of electrons and the transfer of species. Feng and coworkers synthesized Fe single atom anchored hierarchically porous carbon by adding different molar ratios of Zn/Fe. In the process of pyrolysis, the evaporation of Zn2+ increases the distance between Fe atoms avoiding Fe3C@C NPs forming. At the same time, the migration of Zn2+ forms the hierarchically polyporous structure improving the accessibility of Fe-N x moieties [108]. In addition, activators such as KHCO3 and KOH are added to produce pore structures [140]. In the pyrolysis process, the decomposition of the activator produces CO2 gas, which is conducive to the formation and increase of pore size. Jiang and co-workers activated carbon with KHCO3, and more micropores and mesopores were generated compared with unactivated carbon. In addition, after doping nitrogen, the pore size becomes large, and more mesoporous defects appear generated by the N in micropores transferring (Fig. 12g). The catalysts exhibited superior performance in HER and ORR (Fig. 12h) [141]. 3.2.3 Modulation of edge defect in carbon skeletons Edge defects mainly contain zigzag edges and armchair edges as Fig. 13 (a) [142]. At the same carbon atoms of these two edge defects, zigzag edges have more delocalized π electrons performing higher activity than armchair edges, while armchair edges simultaneously can be used to stabilize atoms. Two kinds of edge defects are determined by the different clipping directions on the graphene sheet. Carbon atoms with edge defects have higher charge and spin density than intact carbon atoms [143]. The higher the number of edge defects, the higher its activity [144]. Nakada and coworkers have found that degenerate flat bands occur from 2/3 π to π of the K vector, and localized states occur at the edges when K = π, which are unique to zigzag edges [145]. The zigzag edges have a higher charge spin density than the armchair edges, so the zigzag edges atoms have a faster electron transfer rate and adsorption capacity for oxygen and other substances. In addition, zigzag edge defects are more easily oxidized than armchair defects, so they can be oxidized and modified to increase charge density [142]. Shui and coworkers obtained oxygen-containing functional groups through KMnO4 oxidation, then freeze-dried and pyrolyzed, at the same time, multi-layer carbon nanotubes with open chains were obtained (Fig. 13b). The oxidation process not only increases oxygen-containing functional groups but also facilitates the rupture of carbon–carbon bonds, thus creating conditions for obtaining zigzag edge defects. Zigzag edge defects were formed during subsequent pyrolysis. The obtained catalysts have high power density (520 W g−1 at the loading amounts of 0.25 mg cm−2) of in proton exchange membrane fuel cells, which indicates that the carbon with zigzag edge defects can improve the catalytic activity (Fig. 13c). The DFT proves that the carbon with zigzag edge carbon atoms has a lower energy barrier than a plane, armchair, and O-zigzag edge carbon atoms in Fig. 13(d) [146]. Armchair edge defects exhibit better durability in reaction after carbonization than zigzag edge defects [48]. Furthermore, carbon atoms binding to graphene nitrogen atoms around the edge of the armchair can act as active sites. Li and coworkers used a gas-foaming method to synthesize nitrogen-contained defect catalysts. The gas produced during the pyrolysis process promoted the formation of defects (Fig. 13e). The catalysts showed catalytic performance in ORR, OER, and HER reactions; further, they were assembled in ZABs manifesting an ultralong cycle life (over 330 h) at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13f) [147]. Catalytically active carbon nanowires with edge defects were obtained through oxidation under acidic conditions and pyrolysis, and the synthesized A-PN + C5 site of the armchair defects was conducive to the OER reaction via theoretical calculation [148]. Modulation of carbon local structure around metal active sites can determine the catalytic properties. The Fe-N4 active sites at the edge perform better activity than Fe-N4 at the plane [149]. However, edge defects make the graphene carbon unstable. The Fe clusters facilitate the formation of graphene carbon. In addition, the removal of Fe clusters next to Fe-N4 formed edge-rich Fe-N-C catalysts. Through DFT calculation, the charge density distribution images in Fig. 13(g) show the asymmetric electron distribution and more charge value of edge-Fe-N4 sites. The spin density diagrams (Fig. 13h) illustrate the spin polarization of edge-Fe-N4 sites. These characterizations contribute to edge-Fe-N4 sites accelerating electron transfer and boosting ORR catalysis [149]. 3.2.4 Modulation of heteroatom doping in carbon skeletons The modification of the carbon skeletons structure by the introduction of heteroatoms can effectively affect the electron configuration of the central metal site, thus optimizing the electrocatalytic activity of the MN x part. The relevant modulation method of heteroatom doping is introduced as follows: External N (including pyridine-N (PN) and graphite-N (GN)) are introduced near FeN4 as electron acceptors to regulate its electron distribution and improve its ORR activity. The theoretical calculation shows that the electron redistribution and local electric field at Fe site are significantly enhanced after PN is introduced compared with GN. Synchrotron X-ray absorption spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) confirmed that the introduction of PN induced Fe positive charge accumulation at FeN4 site. The positive charge accumulation contributes to the rapid adsorption of oxygen on active sites and thus improves the performance of SACs [150]. Another report is about doping S to the second coordination sphere of Fe1-NC. The doping can induce the transformation of spin polarization configuration. After DFT, the lower spin state date of Fe center with the doping of S has the low OH* desorption energy [151]. The above modulation methods can provide the way for carbon skeletons of heteroatom doping SACs. 3.3 Summary of design of carbon skeletons Various types of carbon skeleton are introduced, which can provide reference for the preparation of carbon-based catalysts. Hollow structures can be constructed by template or by adding metal-organic frameworks. The core-shell structure can be formed by metal core, carbon shell, or double ZIF composite. The hierarchically porous structures studied more frequently are prepared by template etching method and the pyrolysis of foam MOFs. In the carbon skeleton, the defect structure has higher catalytic activity than the basic structure, and the defect structure can redistribute the local electron density, so that it has a strong affinity for the intermediate product. The vacancy is formed by chemical reagent (H2O2) reduction, metal atom evaporation and high temperature pyrolysis. The pore structure is used by template etching and chemical reagent (KHCO3, KOH) method. Edge defects are usually oxidized by oxidizing agents (KMnO4) and gas foaming. The formation of these defect structures has an important impact on the physical and chemical properties of materials. In the future, according to the inspiration of nature and things in life, more types of carbon skeleton can be explored, such as flower type and accordion type. In the defect structure, the types of vacancies can be developed towards new anion vacancies (B, C, and Cl) and more metal cation vacancies [152]. Edge defects can also be constructed on a carbon skeleton with doped atoms. Even though carbon skeletons have advantages of high conductivity, big surface area and ease of doping atoms, carbon skeletons are not suitable for OER process, because the carbon matrix will be oxidized into carbonate species when increasing the applied positive potentials, which inevitably cause the collapse of single-atom catalyst system. The ORR of the carbon-based SACs showed excellent performance under alkaline conditions but low activity under acidic conditions. More efficient acidic carbon-based SACs should be researched for practical electrocatalysis especially fuel cells. With respect to the modulation of carbon skeletons, there are some modulation strategies of electronegativity regulation, hydrophilic regulation and surface acid-alkaline regulation needing to study further. In the future, the modulation of defect structure should pay more attention to the relationship between defect construction and performance improvement, so as to better construct defect structure. 4 Structural design of different dimension nanocarbon-based SACs 4.1 0D nanocarbon-based SACs 0D nanocarbon-based materials mainly contain nanodots (NDs) and nanospheres. Carbon nanodots (CNDs) have photoluminescence, photocatalytic properties, corrosion resistance, rich functional groups, high stability, and electron mobility [153,154]. However, the small surface area of carbon nanodots would result to low current density and catalytic activity in that carbon shell of small size pores. CNDs have differently doped categorizations, such as boron, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur non-metal doped CNDs, and transition metal ruthenium, platinum, gadolinium, terbium and p-block metal silicon, germanium, selenium doped CNDs. Graphite oxide, graphene sheets, citric acid, poplar leaf and so on have been used to be carbon precursors to synthesize CNDs. CNDs catalysts primarily catalyze photocatalytic HER because of the different wave lengths from UV to NIR and transfer electrons fluently. CNDs can be synthesized by various methods. The hydrothermal method is a common method to synthesize CNDs and has potential to achieve large-scale applications. Recently, Zhuang et al. synthesized N-doped lignin-based carbon dots (NLCDs) by hydrothermal method. Namely, alkali lignin (AL), ethylenediamine and H2O2 were dissolved and then sealed into autoclaves holding 190 °C for 12 h. Then, Pt atoms were bonded with Pyridinic N through photoreduction with 300 W Xe-lamp illuminating. Pt-NLCDs@CdS exhibited visible-light-driven photocatalytic H2-evolution (PHE) rate up to ∼46.10 mmol h−1 g−1. High catalytic activity benefits from the good conductivity of supporter and rich functional surface groups [155]. Chitosan as a carbon source and TiO2 as a photocatalytic conductor can generate electron when absorbing visible light. After the solvothermal carbonization, the addition of TiO2 enhances the photocatalytic HER [156]. CNDs with small sizes can adsorb metal precursors and avoid the aggregation of metal atoms. Another method of single atom anchored CNDs is pyrolysis. CDs, phytic acid (PA), Ru ions (RuCl3·3H2O), and Co ions [Co(NO3)2·6H2O] formed a polymer and then were heated at 1000 °C for 2 h. During the process of pyrolysis, the CDs also spliced together into carbon nanosheets benefiting to load more active sites, and the product cobalt phosphide (CoP) facilitates hydrogen adsorption (Fig. 14 a) [157]. Besides hydrothermal method, microwave method is also an efficient way to prepare large-scale CNDs. Precursor citric acid monohydrate and urea were added to a microwave rector with 15 bar pressure, and then pressure-synthesized carbon nanodots (pCNDs) were synthesized. Afterward, oxidized CNDs were obtained via lamp or sunlight shining (Fig. 14b). The O-CNDs of 90 min shining exhibited the highest photocatalytic HER activity [158]. Nanospheres can expose abundant active sites and contact reactants maximum because of the big surface area and unique shape. He and his coworkers designed Fe SACs anchored on the outer surface of N-doped carbon nanospheres (OAC) with atom utilization efficiency (UE) of 80% for ORR. Fig. 14(c) portrays the synthesis of OAC with polydopamine nanospheres (PDAS) synthesis and following with coating PDAS on SiO2. Next, PDAS@SiO2 was dispersed in an anhydrous FeCl3 solution, with pyrolysis and following leach with HCl. Finally, the products were pyrolyzed for the second time, and then the Fe atom was anchored on the outer shell of nanospheres. The addition of Fe ion after coating layer and SiO2 were added can avoid metal ions encapsulating in carbon composition, thus exposing more active sites. Samples added Fe ions firstly were synthesized as references (IAC) with reduced catalytic activity through a test justified by quantitative UE calculation coinciding with Mossbauer spectroscopy. The OAC exhibited higher half potential (0.854 V) than IAC (0.811 V) via LSV in 0.1 M KOH. The addition of FeCl3 improved atom UE compared to the first addition of FeCl3 [159]. Janus nanospheres realize two different reactions happening on two opposite sides. Janus structures realize bifunctionality well through manipulating catalytic properties via interfacial electron coupling. Janus graphene hollow nanospheres (GHSs) with Ni-N4 of inner shells and Fe-N4 of outer shells were synthesized by Fu. In order to anchor two kinds of active sites at separate sides, SiO2@[Ni(CN)4]2-@GO was firstly formed, and then iron (II) phthalocyanine (FePc) was dispersed in dimethyl formamide (DMF) solution. Subsequently, SiO2@[Ni(CN)4]2-@GO surfaces were coated with FePc to produce core-shell of SiO2@[Ni(CN)4]2-@GO@FePc. Then intermediate products were pyrolyzed under 700 °C in inert gases and subsequently washed with NaOH to remove SiO2 templates yielding Ni-N4/GHSs/Fe-N4 as Fig. 14(d). The respective Ni-N4/GHS and GHS/Fe-N4 were synthesized with similar technology to observe active sites of every side clearly. The bright dots can be seen located uniformly on the surface of inner and outer of GHSs via AC-STEM image. High specific surface area and separate dual-sites of Janus hollow nanosphere are responsible for the high bifunctionality including ORR and OER [53]. 4.2 1D nanocarbon-based SACs The 1D nanostructure can be divided into the following categories, such as nanofibers, nanotubes, nanorods, nanowires, etc. These nanostructures possess interconnected networks, hollow multiwall surfaces and high degree of graphitization contributing to high stretchability and compliance, big surface area, enough active sites, better electric conductivity and structural passability. Further, 1D nanostructure catalysts can be employed as free-standing and binder-free electrodes and applied in energy storage and conversion devices [159–161]. The electron spinning technique has been widely used in synthesizing 1D nanocarbon-based SACs. Researcher synthesized Co/Zn dual-atomic sites anchored on N-doped carbon nanofibers (Co/Zn-NCNF) through electrospinning, annealing and post-procession procedures [162]. Firstly, the precursors nanofibers were composed of polyacrylonitrile (PAN), Pluronic F-127, metal source: cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) and nanosized zinc oxide (ZnO) stirring into emulsion then proceeded electrospinning. The porous carbon fibers were obtained by carbonization of PAN and F-127 upon annealing in an insert and following reduced atmosphere. Then the products were immersed in 0.5 M H2SO4 for 6 h to remove metal nanoparticles. At last, Co/Zn dual atom N doped carbon nanofibers were generated after the same re-pyrolysis process (Fig. 15 a). The addition of ZnO avoids the over evaporation of Zn and makes abundant pores. Paired Co/Zn atomic sites were uniformly dispersed on carbon nanofibers verified by aberration-corrected STEM microscopy (Fig. 15b). Recently, Yan and co-workers developed a time, cost-efficient method, to synthesize carbon-based SA-nanofibers [163]. A schematic of electrospinning process and subsequent heat treatment is shown in Fig. 15(c). In contrast to the last method, the preparation only needs one step of pyrolysis. The ZnFeCo-NC precursor solution for electrospinning dissolved in DMF solution has a good consistency and similar functionality with the polyacrylonitrile (PAN), and thus it only experienced one-step pyrolysis without further acid washing. Fe1Co1-CNF catalysts possessing FeN3CoN3 active sites exhibited a bifunctionality of ORR/OER, which can be used as a free-standing electrode assembled in flexible ZABs. Besides, the catalysts film performs a high specific power of 201.7 mW cm−2 and excellent cycling stability in liquid ZAB (Fig. 15d). Biomass carbon is increasingly used as the ideal support applied to electrocatalysis devices. Biomass materials with surface adjustability, specifical pore and channel structure, and some unique elements have been used in various fields. Liu and coworkers used another pretreatment method pyrolyzing cattail under a reduction atmosphere synthesizing carbon nanofibers (Fig. 15e). Subsequently, the activator and N-doped dopants were induced to make pores and modify the surface electron distribution [164]. This method is suitable for integral structures without being damaged. The fiber-shaped structure can be observed with bamboo morphology and even carbon sheet (Fig. 15f and g). The catalysts exhibited small onset overpotential of 70 mV in HER reaction. The template method is one of the most widely used techniques for synthesizing 1D nanotubes. CNTs are offered as templates owing to their adjustable diameter, large-scale production and facile removal properties [156]. Single-wall carbon layer coated on CNTs has been synthesized to anchor single atom active sites [165].
