CNTs can combine other precursors (GO, MOF) to further improve catalytic activity and multifunctionality. Li and co-workers synthesized Fe-N4 active sites on CNTs through pyrolyzing [166]. The MOFs were attached to CNTs via hydrothermal reaction, and then by high-temperature pyrolysis, and the nitrogen-doped carbon bond with Fe atom evenly covered the surface of O-CNTs (Fig. 15h and i). Owing to the conductive and porous network on O-CNTs, the Fe-NC/rOCNT exhibited a fast electron transfer rate. Meanwhile, it reached a length of 1000 h at 10 mA cm−2 cycle stability attributed to the corrosion resistance. SiO2 can also be used as a template to alleviate the thermal aggregation of metal atoms under carbonization by Joo and co-workers [167]. Besides, the doping of P has a positive effect on loading more metal atoms based on the addition of SiO2 [168]. There are more edge defects produced with the NaH2PO2 activation. Then, more pyridinic N is anchored on the carbon supports. The high loading of Fe atoms (∼36%) was achieved in this research. The usage of template usually needs to remove with strong acid and base destroying carbon skeletons and possessing complex process. Therefore, the self-template method is to be developed to synthesize 1D nanocarbon-base SACs. 4.3 2D nanocarbon-based SACs Graphene and carbon nanosheets (NSs) are two main non-metal substrates to anchor single atom active sites. The 2D nanocarbon-based structure has good mechanical character and conductivity [169]. Besides, the defect and porous structure are easily introduced on the substrates. However, single atoms easily aggregate owing to the weak combination of single atoms and carbon nanosheets. The loading of single metal atoms on the 2D nanocarbon substrate surface remains challenging. Some researchers have taken measures as following to solve the above questions. Graphene is usually synthesized via Hummers’ method [169,170]. In recent years, atom layer decomposition (ALD) has been widely applied to synthesize graphene-based SACs. This strategy can precisely control the size, density and number of metal particles on substrates. Sun and co-workers prepared single platinum atoms and clusters supported on N-doped graphene nanosheets (NGNs) by the ALD techniques [171]. Fig. 16 (a) displays the ALD schematic of Pt atoms and clusters anchored on NGNs. The isolated single Pt atoms as well as tiny clusters were uniformly deposited on the surface of graphene (Fig. 16b). By changing the number of ALD cycles, the size, density and loading of Pt atoms could be efficiently controlled. After a number of ALD cycles from 50 to 100, a few single atoms and clusters would change into larger and more nanoparticles. The loading amounts of Fe are 2.1 and 7.6 wt% in 50 and 100 ALD cycles, respectively. When the number of cycles reached 50, the hydrogenation mass activity for ALD50Pt/NGNs catalysts was 10.1 A mg−1. The mass activity of ALD50Pt/NGNs in HER was 7.8 and 37.4 times that of ALD100Pt/NGNs and Pt/C respectively (Fig. 16c). The excellent catalytic performance of ALD50Pt/NGNs is attributed to the numerous single Pt atoms and clusters which have a strong interaction with supports. Besides, the activity and stability of Pt anchored on N-doped graphene are higher than without N-doped. The high activity is also attributed to unique structure of N-graphene. The high electronegativity and the low number of valence electrons occupying the d orbitals affect catalytic performance [171,172]. There is also a simple method for hydrothermal and pyrolysis of raw materials for graphene-based SACs. The needed raw materials contain accessible GO, metal chloride ion salt, H2O2 and NH3 gas, and organic compounds are prevented (Fig. 16d). Firstly, GO, NiCl2·6H2O, and 30% H2O2 were added forming hydrogel during hydrothermal process. The next freeze-drying reduced the tension of Ni-GO to make metal ions stabilized on GO. Then, N atoms from NH3 were anchored on the supports in the process of high-temperature pyrolysis process. The nitrogen from NH3 and oxygen from GO firmly absorbed metal ions, and the ratio of concentration of metal ions, H2O2 and GO was adjusted jointly to avoid metal aggregation. Through ADF-STEM, hierarchical porous layer graphene loading uniform single atom can be observed (Fig. 16e). Overall, the Ni active sites dispersed on the defective layer structure enable charge transfer across SAC complexes hierarchical pore graphene-lowering OOH* formation activation barriers (Fig. 16f) [113]. Zhu and co-workers synthesized Co and Fe dual atoms supported by N and S co-doped 2D carbon nanosheets catalysts (FeCo-NSC). The pathway schematically depicted in Fig. 16(g) describes many stacked polymer layers are able to stabilize metal dual atoms during fabrication. Typical experimental schemes firstly dissolved perfluorotetradecanoic acid (PFTA) and stearic acid (SA) in 1 mL ethanol, Co(C5H5)2 and Fe(C5H5)2 in ethanol, then added water to induce lamellar PFTA/SA micelles self-assembly with respective amphiphilic outer surfaces and interlayers [173]. Subsequently, Co(C5H5)2 and Fe(C5H5)2 were confined to amphiphilic PFTA/SA outer surfaces to produce micelles PFTA/SA/Co(C5H5)2, Fe(C5H5)2, and then the PFTA/SA/Co(C5H5)2, Fe(C5H5)2 outer surface were decorated with poly-pyrrole (PPy) via pyrrole (62 μL) addition to further stabilize Co(C5H5)2 and Fe(C5H5)2 in the triple micellar sandwich structure. Upon hydrogen bonding linked on pyrrole came into being, the subsequently yielded PPy was heated (150 °C, 8 h) to form a free-standing hydrogel via PPy polymerization. Finally, samples were freeze-dried and pyrolyzed (1000 °C, 1 h, Ar atmosphere), then cooled to yield the final FeCo-NSC products. The Fe-Co dual atoms sites separately disperse on 3D hierarchically porous nanosheets verified by AC-HAADF-STEM and XAS (Fig. 16h and i). Bimetal active sites can strongly anchor each of two O atoms conductive to O–O bond breaking. Therefore, each reaction step is an exothermic reaction accelerating reaction rate. At the same time, the catalysts used in electrochemical applications are generally generated by dissolving precursors in solvent, introducing them to form hierarchical layers, using layered structures to polymerization, freeze-drying yielded hydrogel, and pyrolyzing final products [174]. Besides the hierarchically stereo nanosheets, the defective nanosheets also perform superior activity. Chen and coworkers synthesized the edge-rich Fe-N4 single atoms anchored on the highly graphitic nanosheets (Fe/N-G-SAC) by varying the mass ratio of 1,8-diaminonaphthalene (DAN)/FeCl3 [149]. When the mass ratio is 1:10, polymerization, pyrolysis and subsequent acid etching process would form uniform edge-defect SACs. The formed Fe clusters during polymerization reaction catalyzed the growth of graphitic carbon and produced porous structure near Fe-N4 sites. The generated Fe-N4 edge sites are responsible for the half potential of 0.89 V in the ORR and a low charge-discharge voltage gap of 0.78 V in ZABs. Biomass-based carbon materials are used to synthesize nanosheets carbon-based catalysts. Take fructus azedarach as an example, Fructus azedarach first underwent pretreatment that H3PO4 hydrothermal and then KHCO3 pyrolysis activation. The N and P dual-doped carbon (NPDC) was finally obtained through microwave-assisted hydrothermal treatment and high-temperature calcination (Fig. 16j). The sheet-like structure was observed in TEM image of Fig. 16(k) [78]. Besides, animal biomass consisting of the shells and bones of animals is used to synthesize valuable electrocatalysis materials [133,175]. Some biomass materials have some elements in them to generate some catalysts for specific purposes. Ji and coworkers used shrimp shells as raw materials to synthesize the isolated metal SACs embedded in S, N-codoped nanocarbon and N, S elements both from shrimp shells (Fig. 16l) [175]. The shrimp shell was pyrolyzed at 700 °C for 2 h and proceeded acid hydrothermal to remove Ca ions. Then, SNDC and MTPPCl were mixed for ball milling to band together. This method is a facile and low-energy consumption method. Besides, it can be used to synthesize all kinds of non-precious metal catalysts. The shell of a branching animal-derived chitosan can as a carbon source to anchor single atoms. The chitosan provides N atoms coordinated with Mn atoms and the supports have a proper interaction with Mn. The reaction process contains coprecipitation, pyrolysis and acid etching and the second pyrolysis is responsible for the coordination environment [176]. 4.4 3D nanocarbon-based SACs 3D nanocarbon-based structures mainly contain nanocages, nanoboxes and nanocubes. The precursors of these 3D structures consist of MOFs, graphene, COFs, and so on. These materials possess abundant pores and increased amounts of active sites, multiple across-channels accelerating mass transferring and high specific surface area favoring of dispersion of metal ions. In addition, plentiful nanocavities in the 3D structure can be used to trap active sites without other pore-forming agents added and the large surface area is beneficial to the loading of active components and sites for electrocatalytic reaction [177]. The novel catalyst precursors are biomass carbon, especially monolithic carbon, and can be offered as a free-standing electrode without carbon paper and binder. Hence, carbon possesses good electron conductivity and is convenient for usage. There is a low energy consumption method, such as enzymatic hydrolysis generating carbon supports [178]. This method can also be used to synthesize monolithic carbon. Peng and coworkers synthesized single atom catalysts Fe-N-C based on eucalyptus wood-derived porous carbon. The carbon sheets were firstly soaked in FeCl3 solution at 80 °C for 24 h. Next, the final products were obtained by pyrolyzing in NH3/Ar atmosphere and subsequently acid washing. The Lewis acid FeCl3 hydrolyze cellulose and hemicellulose contributes to hierarchically porous and microchannels structure thus conveying outstanding ORR/OER bifunctionality [179]. Some MOFs, especially ZIFs have been widely used as self-sacrificed templates to form SACs of superior catalytic activity [180]. Wu and coworkers reported a superior-performance ORR catalyst based on 3D porous carbon with Fe/Co dual metal sites through high-temperature pyrolysis. 2-methylimidazole (ZIF-8) with Co2+ and Zn2+ were regarded as hosts and FeCl3 molecules regarded as guests. (Fig. 17 a). ZnCo-ZIF was firstly synthesized by the normal temperature mixing, then FeCl3·6H2O was added forming FeCo-N-C after pyrolyzing at 1173 K. At high temperature, the Zn ions were vaporized to avoid metal particles aggregation. At the same time, the Fe ions in carbon supports catalyze C and N elements to generate N-graphene facilitating electron transmission. Fe species also accelerated the decomposition of metal-imidazolate-metal linkages resulting in the formation of cavities and size expansion in MOFs [88]. There are some other precursors compounding 3D organic framework, for example UIO(bpdc) [97], PCN-222 [181] and COFs [182]. Analogously, the precursors have a high surface area, abundant cavities and versatile structures. Zeng and coworkers prepared Fe nanoclusters anchored onto N-doped porous carbon (FeAC@FeSA-N-C) by encapsulating Fe(NO3)3 precursors into molecular cages through a solvothermal method (Fig. 17b). Here, the COF structure with cavities of diameter 2.5 nm. In cavities, both atomically dispersed Fe-N4 sites and Fe atomic clusters consisting of a few atoms can be trapped. These COFs-based catalysts possess plenty of active sites within big cavities showing a high activity to ORR [181]. The integral carbon can combine with other metal-organic frameworks improving catalytic reaction performance. The paulownia wood slices were firstly immersed in a basic solution obtaining activated wood substrates (AWSs) and then calcinated getting activated carbon substrate (ACS). Co/ZIF-8 grew in-situ on AWSs through stirring at room temperature. After the pyrolysis of 900 °C for 3 h, the Co-N@ACS catalysts were formed. The catalysts possessed better ORR activity than biomass-based ACSs and MOF-derived Co-N-C. Meanwhile, the catalysts applied in both solid and aqueous ZABs exhibited high open-circuit voltage and long-term durability (Fig. 17c) [183]. Therefore, catalytically activated carbon plays a synergistic role in improving reaction activity. The 3D porous framework can be constructed by staked graphene sheets. Single Ni atoms coordinated with O graphene-based 3D porous catalysts were synthesized through the NaCl template method [71]. In this synthesis process, after free-drying at −50 °C, a water mixture of nickel chloride (NiCl2), sucrose (C12H22O11), and NaCl was self-assembled into a 3D metal-carbon framework with the encapsulation of Ni precursors (Fig. 17d). This obtained matrix was subsequently calcined in air and then annealed at 700 °C in an argon atmosphere to generate 2D Ni-O-G graphene. Finally, a washing step in water was carried out to obtain 3D hollow Ni-O-G SACs. The NaCl template not only is safe and low-cost but also provides a 3D framework vital for the uniform distribution of single metal atoms in graphene nanosheets. Metal hydroxides or oxides are offered as templates to synthesize 3D stereochemical structures. For example, an SA-Mo-C catalyst was obtained using Fe2O3 nanocubes as the template and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O as a metal precursor and hydrochloride polydopamine as the precursor for the CN shell. Here, Fe2O3 hard templates with an average diameter of 630 nm were first prepared followed by Mo-gemeled polydopamine (PDA) coating through a self-polymerized process to form Fe2O3/Mo-PDA. This material was subsequently annealed at relatively low temperature under an inert atmosphere followed by acid etching to remove Fe3O4 core. Finally, hierarchical SA-Mo-C nanoboxes with multiple Mo active sites dispersed on carbon nanosheet shells were formed via high-temperature pyrolysis in CN x -rich atmosphere [119]. Specific different dimension nanocarbon-based and biomass carbon-based SACs have respective preparation strategies summarized as follows. 0D nanocarbon contains carbon nanodots and carbon nanospheres, carbon nanodots use hydrothermal and photoreduction, high-temperature pyrolysis and microwave-assisted methods, while carbon nanospheres are synthesized by template method. 1D nanocarbons have carbon nanofibers and carbon nanotubes obtained by electrospinning and template method. 2D nanocarbons named carbon nanosheets mainly are synthesized by ALD and wet chemistry methods to form Single atom catalysts. MOFs are the majority for the synthesis of 3D nanocarbon SACs through high-temperature pyrolysis. Other 3D nanocarbon SACs are prepared through template method. Besides, some biomass derived 3D nanocarbon-based SACs are obtained via the chemical activation of activator and subsequent high-temperature pyrolysis. 4.5 Summary of structural design of different dimension nanocabon-based SACs Different dimension nanocarbon is sorted to design wanted dimension nanocarbon-based SACs with suitable precursors. Each dimension nanocarbon supports possess unique advantages towards different reactions. 0D nanocarbon-based materials mainly contain nanodots (NDs) and nanospheres, carbon nanodots use hydrothermal, photoreduction, and high temperature pyrolysis, while carbon nanospheres are synthesized by template method. Besides, the preparation of Janus nanospheres is using SiO2 coated Ni salts and Fe salts respectively. 1D nanocarbons have carbon nanofibers and carbon nanotubes obtained by electrospinning or the treatment of biomass and template method respectively. 2D nanocarbons contain graphene prepared by Hummer method, ALD, or hydrothermal and carbon nanosheets prepared by the polymerization of compounds or the treatment of biomass. 3D nanocarbon-based SACs are synthesized by decomposing integral biomass or the modulation of 3D organic frameworks or the combination of MOFs and biomass. There are many more substances in nature that need to be discovered as the precursors of nanocarbon-based SACs [184]. There is still room for further exploration of nano-carbon materials with different dimensions, and these carbon materials should be developed towards higher activity and stronger stability. 5 Structure analyses of carbon-based SACs The characterization of material can reflect morphology, structure and mechanism to prove to design goal catalysts. Meanwhile, the research is guided to study the relationship between structure and performance. The characterization part of carbon-based SACs is classified into active sites and carbon skeletons, and the spectroscopy of reaction process and reaction mechanism. The detailed methods of each part are summarized in Fig. 18 . 5.1 Determination of active sites The diameter of a single atom is angstrom or sub-angstrom. Isolated atoms are observed usually by high-resolution electron microscopy, such as AC-STEM, sometimes combining HAADF. The AC-STEM also discerns the active sites in the form of atoms, clusters or nanoparticles. Relevant element dispersion spectroscopy can discern the sorts and scattered states of elements. At the same time, the observation is direct proof of the dispersion and spatial distribution of metal atoms. Low-resolution electron microscopy is the key characterization to synthesize SACs because it shows the influence of reaction conditions on products [185]. Observing the morphology of the low-loading catalysts is of significance to searching the relation between morphology and performance. Electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) is used to observe the sorts and environment of coordinating atoms. XPS can further determine the chemical state of metal ions. Besides, XAS can obtain the types of coordinated atoms, coordinated atom numbers, and coordinated structures. As shown in Fig. 19 (a), PtNPC-0.5 catalysts with the isolated Pt centers coordinated with N atoms in the first shell were ascertained by HAADF-STEM [107]. The isolated atom sites can be viewed as bright dots with white circles. Additionally, EELS revealed the local coordinated atoms N and C around Pt single atoms. The P atoms were not detected because of their low content. By the elemental mapping, all the elements of Pt, N, P and C were presented with uniform dispersion (Fig. 19b). In order to know Pt metal centers clearly, XANES spectra of PtNPC-0.5 were conducted in Fig. 19(c) to get their white line intensity of Pt L 3-edge adsorption peaks between Pt foil and PtO2. The Pt oxidation state in PtNPC-0.5 is close to +2, and the Pt is in form of a single atom. Fig. 19(d) depicts EXAFS analysis to further validate Pt SAC dispersion uniformity and coordination environment over PtNPC-0.5. Corresponding FT-EXAFS analysis resolves a notable peak (∼1.96 Å) corrected with Pt-N scattering paths. However, Pt–Pt bond characteristic peaks of Pt foil were not detected in PtNPC-0.5, validating the isolation of Pt SACs in PtNPC-0.5. Combining the DFT calculations, the coordination number (CN) of Pt-N x sites is around 3.07 (Pt-N3) in the PtNPC-0.5. Simultaneously, the absence of Pt-P peak demonstrates there is no P coordination in the first shell of Pt atom. Porous S-doped Fe-N-C nanosheets (Fe-NSDC) with Fe-NS ligand complexes were synthesized by Zhu and coworkers [186]. Firstly, numerous Fe single atoms of Fe-NSDC were identified by HAADF-STEM. Fig. 19(e) displays EELS with N, S, and Fe peaks from the circled single atom by HADDF-STEM, which proves Fe coordinated with N and S atoms. Fig. 19(f) depicts Fe 2p XPS spectra for Fe-NSDC with two doublet peaks attributed to Fe2+ (710.9 and 724.3 eV) and Fe3+ (717.6 and 730.4 eV) species and the content of Fe2+ is more than the content of Fe3+ knowing from the intensity of peak. Fig. 19(g and h) portrays FT-EXAFS, resolving a Fe-N coordination (1.96 Å) after the fitting, and the number ratio of Fe-N and Fe-S is close to 3:1. The above results all demonstrate the Fe coordinated with N and S. Further, bimetal active sites were synthesized to reduce ORR reaction energy barrier in acid electrolytes [88]. The connected bimetal active sites were first observed in magnified HAADF-STEM (Fig. 19i). The connected bright dots and the corresponding intensity profiles manifest the dispersion of bimetal atoms. The adsorption energy peak sites of N K-edge XAS of (Fe, Co)/N-C are the same as FePc and CoPc and show the isolated atom form (Fig. 19j). Besides, the intensity of σ* band is lower than π* band related to the reduction of CN double bond and maintenance of MN bond. Fe K-edge EXAFS fittings of (Fe, Co)/N-C in Fig. 19(k) illustrate the experimental results identical with Fe–Co bond length (2.5 Å) and three Fe-N coordination. The adsorption energy of Fe K-pre-edge is larger than Fepc, and Fe2O3 and the results demonstrated that Fe is reduced by metal–metal bond and unsymmetric coordination structure (Fig. 19l). 5.2 Characterization of carbon skeletons Carbon supports are of significance for the catalytic activity in reactions, thus it is necessary to discuss the relevant carbon component to understand the reason for performance improvement. The crystal form of carbon was tested by powder X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (P-XRD). The bonding form of carbon is identified through XPS. The defects in carbon skeletons are very common. The defects of carbon skeletons are vital for the research of relation between structure and catalytic performance. Raman spectrum is conducted to get the ratio of graphene C and defect C, which means pyrrole and pyridine carbons. If there are pore structures in carbon skeletons, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm would be conducted to calculate the specific surface area, pore volume and pore width. The other defects like edge or vacancy can be elucidated with DFT, HOMO-LOMO orbital distribution and even HAADF-STEM [187]. In addition, the size of carbon skeletons also affects catalytic performance and can be characterized by DFT. Fe Single atom catalysts are hailed as the best performance catalysts in ORR. Hence, numerous trials have been made by researchers to the comprehension of correlation between active sites and performance. Fe SACs were coupled with nitrogen vacancies (VN) on hollow carbon spheres (Fe-ND/C) to form electrocatalysts [62], fostering charge transfer and thus catalyzing ORR activity. Fig. 20 (a) evaluates the XRD spectra of Fe-ND/C with two broad peaks centered at 24° and 43° corresponding to graphitic carbon and connected to amorphous carbon. The XPS spectra of N 1s can indirectly prove different sorts of carbon through the surrounding electronic structure of carbon atoms. Fig. 20(b) depicts three fitted peaks connected to graphitic-N (401.2 eV), pyrrolic-N (400.2 eV), and pyridinic-N (398.3 eV) bonding [62]. Furthermore, the comparison of Fe-N/C and Fe-ND/C in N 1s XPS spectra demonstrates the lesser pyrrolic N in Fe-ND/C to form N vacancy. The defective degree of carbon can be explained by Raman spectroscopy. The defective band (D) in 1350 cm−1 is disordered carbon, such as pyridinic N, and graphitic band (G) in 1590 cm−1 is graphene carbon. Fig. 20(c) shows that the I D/I G value of Fe-ND/C (0.97) is much higher than Fe-N/C (0.85), which indicates more defective formation in Fe-ND/C. Chen and coworkers synthesized Fe single atoms dispersed on hierarchically micro/mesoporous carbon nanorods catalysts. (Fe/N-CNRs) [127] N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out to obtain the change of amounts and kinds of porous structure and surface area. The surface area of Fe/N-CNRs (666.7 m2 g−1) is larger than Fe/N-CNRs-NW (351.4 m2 g−1) (Fig. 20d). Thus, there are more pore structures in Fe/N-CNRs obtained after experiencing acid washing. The pore size distribution of Fe/N-CNRs is mainly located at micropores and mesopores. The N-CNDs without the addition of Fe2O3 template compared with Fe/N-CNRs have a lower surface area and pore volume (462.6 m2 g−1 and 1.2 cm3 g−1) because the template can avoid the collapse of carbon skeletons during carbonization (Fig. 20e). C 1s XPS profiles of Fe/N-CNRs in Fig. 20(f) have five peaks of CC (284.6 eV), CN (286.1 eV), CO (286.6 eV), CO (287.8 eV), and OCO (289.2 eV). The formation of C–N means the dope of N in carbon supports. The abundant pores and high surface area are responsible for the superior ORR activity. Fe single atoms anchored on different-sized carbon supports perform different performances. Lee and coworkers stated ORR the dynamic behaviors of ORR are affected by the size of graphene (Fig. 20g) [26]. The large-size graphene-based SACs presented better activity than the small-size graphene-based SACs because the small-size graphene possesses more edge defects easily oxidized. Further, the high electron density of π-band in large-size graphene is responsible for the high d-orbital energy level of the Fe-N4 sites. Therefore, a large intermolecular hardness factor (ηDA) of bonds in large-size graphene-based SACs related to the strong interaction between single atoms and intermediates contributes to superior activity (Fig. 20h). Besides, CuN2C2 supported on CNT-8 with 8 nm diameter possesses proper strain contribution to higher ORR activity than CNT-4 with 4 nm [188]. The characterization of different sizes has a great meaning for the promotion of performances. 5.3 Spectrum test of reaction species Knowing the synthesized process and changing situation of active sites are important to investigate the relationship between active site structure and performance and to better design the active site. Therefore, in-situ or operando tests are used to detect the mass changes of every step during the reaction. For the synthesized process of catalysts, in situ transition electron microscopy (TEM) is the direct observation. In-situ infrared spectroscopy (IR) and Raman spectroscopy are primarily the measurement technique of reaction intermediates. IR detects unsymmetric molecules because of changes in the dipole moment. Raman spectroscopy measures symmetric molecules resulting from changes in polarizability. Besides, Raman spectroscopy has good hydrophilicity and is used to detect the changes of active sites [189]. In situ mass spectrum (MS) can obtain the ratio of mass to charge through ionized chemical species to identify reaction intermediates [190]. Li and coworkers found the morphology changes of ZIF-8 before and after the addition of S via in suit environmental TEM. After the addition of S, the size of S-ZIF-8 was shrunken and more porous structure came into being. These results further showed the addition of S not only modified the coordination structure but also formed defect structure [102]. In situ IR detects the formation of metal active sites from CO adsorption tests [191]. Further, the metal center local structure of active sites can be identified. Additionally, the change of catalysts in the catalytic reaction is also detected. CO chemisorption can distinguish from single atom or nanoparticle formation especially for noble metals. The Pt metal single atoms are distinct from nanoparticles supported on HZSM-5 (zeolite-based framework) with characteristic adsorption of the former at 2115 cm−1, while the latter bridge even CO showing the adsorption line of 2070 to 2090 cm−1 [192,193]. In addition, CO adsorption behaviors were affected by the interaction between metal-metal atoms, making CO-diffuse reflective infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) a suitable measure tool to detect metal local structure. Lu and coworkers synthesized Ni1Cu2/g-C3N4 catalysts with Ni atoms linked with 2 Cu atoms active sites tested by the CO-DRIFTS [194]. As shown in Fig. 21 (a), the adsorption peak of Cu is located at 2103 and 2123 cm−1 on isolated Cu1/g-C3N4, while there are no peaks on isolated Ni1/g-C3N4. In NiCu dual atom catalysts, the decreased peak intensity of Cu demonstrated the addition of Ni can interact with Cu and form NiCu bond. In situ attenuated total reflectance surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) was used to obtain the bonding information of reaction intermediate adsorbed on active sites. The changes information of species reaction process is gotten. The determination of rate controlling step and active sites of Fe SAs-Fe2P NPs/NPCFs-2.5 was tested by in-situ ATR-SEIRAS [195]. The tests were first proceeded in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte and the result demonstrated the peak of *O2 − gradually appeared and the intensity of peak decreased from 0.9 to 0.4 V. Meanwhile, the time difference spectrum in 0.8 V performed a similar change and indicated the production of *O2 − (Fig. 21b and c). The results proved the rate-determining step was the adsorption of *O2 − in acid solution. In 0.1 M KOH, the same tests were carried out and revealed the rate-determining step (the formation of OOH* located at 1230 cm−1). The different rate-determining steps in acid and base electrolytes of Fe SAs-Fe2P NPs/NPCFs-2.5 means there may be different active sites in different electrolytes. The changes of reaction intermediate in electrocatalytic reactions detected by ATR-SEIRAS provide the fundamental information to study reaction mechanism. In-situ Raman spectroscopy has the ability to gain the information of catalyst surface and reaction intermediates during catalytic reaction process. At the same time, the interaction of active sites with intermediates can be inferred. The D band and G band can be usually detected to describe the defect degree of carbon supports. The O2* and OOH* intermediates reacting on the active sites of Fe SAs-Fe2P NPs/NPCFs-2.5 were tested by in-situ Raman [195]. In acid electrolyte test, two adsorption peaks appeared at 978 and 1048 cm−1 are attributed to *O2 − and OOH* respectively (Fig. 21d). In base electrolyte test, there is a new peak occurred at 1150 cm−1 (Fig. 21e). The peak ascribed to stretching vibration of OO in O2 − and the intensity of the band increased with the decrease of potential and the results manifested the strong interaction between Fe active sites and O2 −. In-situ MS can identify reaction intermediates qualitatively to know the exact reaction pathway. Operando MS is a convictive tool providing the understanding of underlying reaction mechanisms. Choi and coworkers found the addition of CO increases the reduction current of H2 during HER through differential electrochemical mass spectroscopy (DEMS) [196]. In CV analysis of Pt/HSC with addition of CO flow, there were not CH4, C2H4 and ROH et al (Fig. 21f). Meanwhile, no nonvolatile mass was tested by ex situ nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). Then, under a subsequent Ar-statured gas, the peak intensity of H2 was almost unchanged and illustrated the enhanced role of CO of Pt active sites. The above results demonstrate the high activity of Pt/HSC is attributed to the evolution of H2, not the reduction of CO. 5.4 Theoretical simulation of catalytic mechanism Research of active sites and carbon skeletons during the reaction is vital for deep comprehension of atomic electrocatalytic reaction mechanism. The mechanism can be guidance to modulate the coordination environment of high-performance SACs. Some in-situ characterization such as in-situ near-ambient pressure XPS (NAP-XPS) and in-situ XAS can measure out the local coordination, charge state and stability of active sites in the process of reaction [197,198]. Some simulations and calculations can see the electronic and geometric structure of active sites thoroughly to obtain the interaction of intermediates with active sites and active sites with carbon skeletons. The information can provide guidance to better modulate active sites. In common, the special active sites of the designed catalysts can lower the activation energy of rate-determining step. The preferential CO oxidation (PROX) reaction on Cu SAC loaded with uio-66 was verified by tracking the effect of temperature disturbance on catalytic performance. The changes in electronic tested by in-situ NAP-XPS manifest that as the reaction temperature increases, the number of Cu+ like states increases and the number of ZrOx nodes partially decreases, which is related to the decrease in PROX selectivity and adsorption performance [199]. Wang and coworkers studied the active sites of Cu-N4 for oxygen reduction reaction [200]. Through in-situ XANES, the dynamic modulation of Cu active sites from high valence (+2) to low valance (+1) would adsorb OH* in the process of ORR. The test of Cu-N4 active sites on carbon nanospheres (CuNC) was completed over potentials varying from 1.10 to 0.00 V. As demonstrated in Fig. 22 (a), their first high intensity of Cu K-edge adsorption peaks (B) goes up as the applied voltage goes down. Relative to CuO and Cu2O, CuNC, Cu K-edge energies indicated Cu valence states decreased from +2 to +1 when situated within electrolytes in operando. The further FDMNES simulation displayed the Cu-N4 coordination at 0.82 V, the Cu-N3 coordination at 0.50 V, and the Cu-N2-OH coordination at 0.10 V (Fig. 22b–d). The changes in active sites are caused by the applied potential. The DFT in Fig. 22(e) exhibits Cu-N3 active sites are exothermic while Cu-N4 active sites need to endothermal from O2 to OOH*, and thus the true active sites are Cu-N3 [197]. Lou and coworkers prepared the defective structure and studied the reason for affecting HER activity [201]. First-principles Gibbs free energy calculations show lower H* adsorption in ECM@Ru (with edge defects) than CM@Ru (without edge defects). And the results implied the edge defective structure was conductive to the improvement of activity. Further, the simulated total density of states (TDOS) resolved the ECM@Ru versus CM@Ru producing distinct TDOS profiles, with edge-decorated systems featuring denser TDOS near the Fermi level. This explains why edge structures are easier to adsorb H* (defective sites). For coordination environment, various metal atoms have unique coordination atoms and can achieve the highest performance. Li and coworkers synthesized NiN3S1, CoN3S1, and FeN4S2 coordinated catalysts through the same method [202]. The Mulliken charge density of metal atoms of NiN3S1, CoN3S1 and FeN4S2 is 0.03, 0.09, and 0.11, respectively. The high charge density is beneficial to electron transfer and the adsorption of reactants. Such implications were evidenced by partial density of states (PDOS) analysis in Fig. 22(f), which displayed FeN4S2 has higher state density than NiN3S1 and CoN3S1. The specific reaction mechanism verified by the Gibbs free energy graph and the results demonstrated that the relative smallness OH* desorption of such an energy barrier FeN4S2 (−0.65 eV) versus corresponding NiN3S1 (2.79 eV) and CoN3S1 (1.15 eV) barriers at equilibrium potential can explain ORR activity of FeN4S2 higher than NiN3S1 and CoN3S1 (Fig. 22g). These calculation results substantiate different coordination trends of different metal ions in the same reaction. Besides, the coordination environment affects activity of reaction and the modulation of coordination environment can be used to design catalysts with superior activity. 4d and 5d metals usually perform inferior activity in ORR than 3d transition metals. Xin and coworkers designed a RuN4-S active site through modulation of the second-shell coordination and exhibited elevated ORR activity. The second-shell S coordination of metal atoms can be verified by XANES and XPS. RuN4-S compared with RuN4 decreases the adsorption energy barrier of OH*. The crystal orbitals overlap population (COOP) method based on the interaction between Ru d orbitals and O p orbitals reveals RuN4-S with more antibonding than RuN4 after O* adsorption contributing to the quick splitting of OH*. In addition, DOS of RuN4-S is lower than RuN4 manifesting the lower d-band center (Fig. 22h). The result elaborates on the easy desorption of OH* intermediates. Bader charge analysis illustrates the low Bader charge in RuN4-S resulting in the weak interaction of OH* (Fig. 22i). These performances are attributed to S donating electrons to N decreasing the electron transfer from Ru [203]. 5.5 Summary on structure analyses of carbon-based SACs The characterization of material can reflect morphology, structure and mechanism to prove to design goal catalysts. Meanwhile, the research is guided to study the relationship of structure and performance. And the research is beneficial to design high performance catalysts. The characterization of carbon-based SACs is classified into active sites and carbon skeletons, and the spectroscopy of reaction process and reaction mechanism. Isolated atoms are observed usually with help of high-resolution electron microscopy. XPS can further determine the chemical state of metal ions. Besides, the XAS would cooperate to obtain the types of coordinated atoms, coordinated numbers and coordinated structure. The carbon skeletons can be tested by P-XRD, XPS, Raman spectrum, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and so on. From above aspects, the crystal form, bonding form defect of carbon are revealed. For reaction process, In-situ IR can detect the type of metal atom and the formation of reaction intermediates. In-situ Raman spectroscopy can obtain the interaction between active sites and intermediates concluding reaction process. In situ MS proves the real reaction substances. In situ-XANES, first-principles Gibbs free energy calculations and DOS are used to obtain the true reaction active sites and the reaction mechanism. At present, due to the limitations of catalysts and characterization techniques, direct evidence for the structural characterization of SACs is still insufficient. For example, it is difficult to gain accurate results of many kinds of coordination environment from XAS [204]. Thus, the characterization of SACs always needs a series of complementary techniques. 6 Modulations of electrochemical behavior in energy catalysis 6.1 ORR ORR takes place at the cathode of H2/O2 fuel cells and metal-air batteries. ORR is a green reaction turning the chemical energy into electrical energy. ORR proceeds 4e− transfer pathways from O2 to H2O [205], in addition, with a competitive reaction taking 2e− transfer pathways. 2e− pathway processes generate H2O2 as oxidant. The 4e− pathway of ORR has five elementary steps as follows, and thus it needs high activation energy. The widely used Pt resources are lacking and the utilization is low. Decreasing the size of Pt to atom level can highly solve above questions. Single atom catalysts have high surface activation energy. Furthermore, single atom can easily modulate its electron structure and coordination environment to enhance ORR activity. For different types of active sites, various measures are taken to regulate the rate-determining steps to ensure the interactions between active sites and intermediates [206,207]. Nowadays, commercial Pt/C has low atom utilization and high cost, so it is urgent to develop high atom efficiency and low-cost alternatives to satisfy practical requirements. Cho and coworkers prepared atomically dispersed Pt supported on carbon support through the low-temperature hydrothermal ethanol reduction method and the high-temperature pyrolysis (Fig. 23 a). The process of high-temperature pyrolysis contributed to the formation of well-distributed Pt NPs. The prepared Pt1@Pt/NBP was made of single atoms and Pt NPs. Besides, this process made more defects and N-coordination, which formed new coordination environment tested by XPS and XAFS. Pt1@Pt/NBP with 5 wt% Pt exhibited an excellent H2O selectivity of 99.47%, with a half potential of 0.867 V in 0.1 M HClO4 (Fig. 23b). In order to achieve high activity of ORR, one effective method is to select suitable method to optimize the coordination environment of Pt active sites [34]. In addition, other metal active sites such as Fe, Co, Cu, Mn, etc. supported on carbon supports were also reported and exhibited excellent performance. Herein, generally good-performance catalysts are Fe-based SACs. Both theoretical and experimental results justify the above discussion. Thus, numerous works were done to synthesize all kinds of Fe single atoms on carbon matrix through a variety of techniques and ways. Among these synthesizing ways, pyrolyzing Fe-contained MOFs is a frequently used strategy for obtaining isolated Fe atom catalysts [124,208]. Zhang and coworkers successfully designed Fe SAC-MIL101-1000 catalysts using high-temperature pyrolysis of Fe-containing NH2-MIL-101(Al) [67]. These MOFs compared with ZIF-8 possess bigger pore diameter and more mesopores [209], and the catalysts show an ultrahigh ORR activity with a half-wave potential of 0.94 V (Fig. 23c), high kinetic current density (37.14 mA cm−2 at 0.9 V) as well as better methanol tolerance and stability than Pt/C (Fig. 23d and e). At the same time, the catalysts exhibited a high specific capacity of 724.0 mA h kgZn −1 in solid zinc-air batteries and excellent energy density of 984.2 W h kgZn −1 in aqueous zinc-air batteries. Wu and coworkers reported a pyridinic-N coordinated Co single atom supported on MOF-derived carbon materials via lysozyme-modified method. High-temperature pyrolysis on carbon cloth ionically substitutes Co2+ into the Zn2+ sites of ZIF-8 to form Single atom catalysts with higher Zn/Co ratio (9:1). Besides, the addition of lysozyme increased the amounts of pyridinic-N during pyrolysis, thus the Co content in Co-pyridinic N-C catalyst was close to 2.14 wt%, much higher than Co-N-C catalysts (1.38 wt%). Fig. 23(f and g) presents the LSV curves of various catalysts and the optimal catalysts have higher ORR potential of half wave in KOH electrode, and excellent ORR onset potentials in H2SO4 solution. Such stable activity was ultimately attributed to the advantageous and balanced bonding of Co-pyridinic N-C ligand complexes to OOH* intermediates, and the more prevalent Co-pyridinic N4 coordination has reduced electron localization in adsorbing O2 during ORR reaction (Fig. 23h and i) [210]. Above all, the ORR performance of carbon-based SACs of different metals is summarized in Table 1 [34,67,82,102,103,127,128,210–212]. It is found that the Pt group metals exhibit higher ORR activity compared with non-noble metal under acidic conditions, while Fe metals usually exhibit high ORR properties under acidic conditions. Co metals exhibit excellent ORR properties under both acidic and alkaline conditions. The performance is improved after doping non-metallic atoms. In addition, other transition metals Mn, Cu and main group metals Mg also exhibit high activity in ORR. 6.2 OER OER is the reserve reaction of ORR happening on the positive pole in metal-air batteries and negative pole in water splitting reaction. The reaction plays an important role in the efficient energy storage and conversion devices. And the application of electrochemical devices alleviates the consumption of fossil fuels. Similarly, the OER possesses four steps involving removal of hydrogen ions of OH* intermediates and the formation of OO bonds [6,213]. Currently, RuO2 is generally used as commercial OER catalysts. However, great efforts are necessary to find low-cost and high-efficiency catalysts to meet the practical application. Many strategies have been presented to improve the OER activity, including (1) the modulation of electron structure of metal active sites; and (2) the mediation of the electron transferring rate between metal single atoms and supports. Li and coworkers developed a facile and efficient method for fabricating Ru single atom supported on graphdiyne (GDY) for OER [214]. At the overpotential of 2.0 V, Ru/GDY shows an enhanced OER performance with j mass of 9.03 A mgmetal −1, which is 7.05 times larger than Ru NP/GDY (Fig. 24 a). GDY as a support can donate electrons to Ru ions. This effect slows down the electron transfer between reaction intermediates and active sites and strengthens the interactions with O-contained intermediates [215]. This catalyst also shows excellent stability (Fig. 24b). Besides the noble metal, the other non-noble metals, such as, Ni and Co and Fe also perform preferable OER activity. Jiang and coworkers synthesized Ni-O-G SACs using sucrose and nickel chloride as the resources and the atomic and electronic Ni center with O4(OH)2 coordination were identified (Fig. 24c). The bigger electronegative O enhances electron extraction from the Ni contributing to the active site of high-valence Ni2.37+. As a result, the H left of OH* gets easier because of the strong link O-intermediates with Ni metal centers in Ni-O-G SACs (Fig. 24d). The catalysts exhibited a very low overpotential of 224 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1 M KOH electrode (Fig. 24e) [71]. In addition, dual-metal atom NiFe supported on graphene oxide (GO) shows excellent OER performance [216]. Through changing the ratio of Ni/Fe, the Ni4Fe1-O-G SACs are the most active for OER among all different ratio catalysts. Catalysts not only showed low overpotential, but also excellent performance for water oxidation during the continuous time of 48 h. Graphene is reported as a common support to synthesize SACs for OER. It is urgent to explore other carbon-based supports to catalyze OER efficiently. Calcium carbide (CaC2) was recently proved to catalyze OER combining Co-TPP-Br through a facile and fast ball-milling method by Liu and coworkers [192]. The catalyst supports synthesized through the reaction CaC2 with Co-TPP-Br has the ability to load Co single atom with CoN4 coordination. The Co is + 2 valent tested by XANES, XPS, and DFT. Apart from higher Bader charge, the comparison of free energy landscape of Co-BM-C SACs and Co/NP-C also exhibited an excellent OER performance in single atom catalysts (Fig. 24f and g). The catalysts show low overpotential of 240 mV in 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 24h) [217]. For OER, the types of transition metals are mostly limited to Ni and Co supported on carbon-based materials. Surprisingly, the synthesized Fe-based SACs exhibited excellent OER activity. Fe-N coordination catalysts were prepared through the free-drying of dicarbonyl dinitrosyl iron (Fe(CO)2(NO)2) and N-doped graphene quantum dots (N-GQDs) by Chen and coworkers [218]. N-GQDs aided with PyBr3 were firstly synthesized by hydrothermal method. The 1.5-Fe(NO)2eN-GQD with addition of 0.0255 mg of Fe(CO)2(NO)2 shows the optimal OER activity with an overpotential of 270 mV in 1 M KOH among different mass ratios of Fe/C supports. In summary, in addition to the commonly used Ru showing high OER activity in acidic conditions, the transition metal Ni and the combination of Ni and another metal Co and Fe also show excellent OER performance. Other Co and Fe can also catalyze OER. The relevant OER performance of different matel-based SACs are summarized in Table 2 [71,117,214,216–221]. 6.3 HER The hydrogen evolution reaction is the half-reaction of electrocatalytic water splitting. The reaction possesses two steps: the first step: H+ + * + e− → H*; the second step: H+ + e− + H* →H2 + *. In addition, there are still other pathways to generate H2, for example, photocatalysis and ammonia borane or sodium borohydride [222]. Hydrogen energy fuel batteries are a new kind of clean energy with an energy density of 33.3 kW h kg−1, and the batteries have potential to be the next generation of energy devices. Besides, the devices greatly reduce the consumption of carbon. Pt and platinum group metals have been known as the promising catalysts used in HER in acid electrolytes. Owing to the urgent need to achieve high atom utilization, Pt SACs are explored and exhibited high performance in HER. In order to improve the activity, stability and selectivity of HER, the non-noble metal has also been proven to efficiently catalyze the HER reaction. Amal and coworkers synthesized Pt SACs supported by vertically aligned edge-defect graphene (denoted as Pt/VG Ar-5) [223]. The Pt/VG Ar-5 displayed a high electrocatalytic activity for HER with an overpotential of 124 mV at 10 mA cm−2 of Pt/VG Ar-5 and was lower than Pt/VG Ar-0 without defect (173 mV) and commercial Pt/C (199 mV) (Fig. 25 a). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements (Fig. 25b) explain charge transfer kinetics, with fitted results calculating lower charge transfer resistance in Pt/VG Ar-5 than in Pt/VG Ar-0. The superior performance demonstrates that the edge-coordinated Pt SACs also show potential for alkaline HER. The designed strategy creates a new route to design the sustainable catalysts of defect coordination. Ru single atom composite (Ru1CoP/CDs) catalysts were prepared by Lu and coworkers [157]. This catalyst was applied in HER and emphasized catalytic performance as the maximization in alkaline 1 M KOH and acid. Even if Pt has exhibited high performance in HER, researchers find out other non-noble metals on carbon supports, such as Mo, Co, and Ni SACs, perform superior HER activity. Xue and coworkers designed MoO1N1C2 coordination active sites anchored on N-doped multichannel carbon nanofibers and this catalyst shows an overpotential of 66 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 (Fig. 25c). The DFT calculations reveal that the O, N and C coordination modulate the electron structure of catalysts and benefit to hydrogen adsorption, thus improving the catalytic activity (Fig. 25d) [104]. Recently, MoO2C2 active sites proposed have higher activity than MoONC coordination by Lu and coworkers [224]. Based on various theoretical and experimental studies, the SACs formed a stronger interaction on O2C2 moieties compared with previous O2N1C2 and O2N2 coordinated structures, therefore resulting in lower overpotential in KOH electrolyte (Fig. 25e). More importantly, researchers also confirmed that Mo with C coordination increased more d band center than without C coordination (Fig. 25f). This coordination environment was formed by EtOH and 1,10-phenanthroline chelating with Mo facilitating Mo anchored on carbon black. Ni SACs have also been widely applied in HER [117,218]. At the same time, the vacancy sites in SACs also exhibit high activity. Yao and coworkers proposed a vacancy graphene to stabilize Ni SACs [117]. The vacancies/defects graphene-supported Ni SAs were synthesized through a thermal aggregation process and subsequent HCl etching. Ni SACs can bond to seven adjacent carbon atoms contributed by the combination of two five-membered rings and two seven-membered rings. Due to the strong interactions between Ni SAs and defect graphene, the defect surface showed lower desorption energy of H+ than perfect and di-vacancy carbon place (Fig. 25g). As a result, the local electric field of Ni sites exhibits a greater activity than perfect carbon because of the induced migration of the ion (H+) reactant (Fig. 25h, i). To sum up, Ru is commonly used in HER, and some Pt metals can also show high activity. Non-noble metal Mo has high activity in HER. Co with different coordination environment perform superior HER performance. Other transition metal Ni with specific defect structure can show high HER activity. The HER performance of different metal-containing carbon-based SACs are summarized in Table 3 [104,156,157,223–229]. 6.4 HOR HOR takes place on anode of the fuel cell in the discharge process. HOR and HER are two reversible reactions, and HOR produces electrons and proton from H2. This reaction turns H2 energy into electric energy in PEMFC. In the process of discharge, the kinetics of HOR is at least six orders of magnitude faster than ORR of cathodic reaction because of the 2 electrons transfer pathway. In general, Pt-based catalysts have been widely used in practical devices. However, the scarcity of Pt constrains Pt-based catalysts on a large scale. At present, besides Pt-based metals, the Ru metal is mainly studied. The research of HOR is still rarer than HER. Besides, carbon-based materials especially MOF and biomass-based carbon possess the worse conductivity and corrosion resistance, thus the carbon-based materials applied in HOR are few. To sum up, the other metal and carbon supports should be largely explored. Li and coworkers reported a Pt single atom anchored on N-doped carbon nanosheets catalyst (Pt-NCS). The carbon supports possess abundant N contents of 12.1 at% and many pores and resulting in the excellent HOR activity. It showed a mass activity of 2.04 A mgPt −1 better than 20% Pt/C (0.31 A mg−1 Pt) even though its metal loading is ultralow (Fig. 26 a). As a HER/HOR bifunctional catalyst, Pt-NCS was assembled in a fuel cell device delivering a power density of 0.58 W cm−2 at a current density of 1.0 A cm−2 near 20% Pt/C (Fig. 26b) [230]. During the process of discharge in H2-O2 fell cells, the ORR reaction would take up the anode hindering the process of HOR. Nakanishi and coworkers designed a Pt single atom anchored on covalent triazine frameworks (Pt-CTF), which can reduce the happening of ORR [73]. The prepared catalysts exhibited superior performance equivalent to commercial 20 wt% Pt/C (Fig. 26c). At the same time, a small decrease in current density when the input gas changed to H2/O2 (1:1) (Fig. 26d). It proves that oxygen cannot react on anode because of the atomically dispersed Pt atoms and high surface area of supports. Afterward, Siahrostami and coworkers found that the Ru single atom supported on N-doped divacancy graphene (Rh@N-DV-Gr) is active to the HOR through DFT calculations [14]. Its activity even exceeds Pt-based catalysts. The divacancy in graphene was considered to modulate the electron structure of active centers and thus affected the catalytic activity [231]. Li and coworkers found coordinated sulfur atoms around Ru-N4 sites tuning the local electron structure and thus improving the HOR activity [75]. Integrating with the FT-EXAFS and quantitative EXAFS curve fitting analyses, Ru-N4-S2-C moieties of RuNS were confirmed. The RuN4 moiety modified with 2 sulfur atoms lowered the energy barrier from H2O to H*/OH* compared with RuN4 according to DFT calculations. Moreover, the RuSA/NSG exhibited higher mass activity at overpotential of 0.05 V than Ru/C (6.1 times) and Pt/C (3.5 times) (Fig. 26e). After 2000 CV cycles, the RuSA/NSG still maintained stable operation and relative current-time chronoamperometry and response also kept 87.3% current after 10 h (Fig. 26f). The above results prove the superior stability of RuSA/NSG in HOR process. 6.5 Summary of the regulation of electrocatalytic reaction by monoatomic catalyst Single atom catalysts are mainly used for homogeneous catalysis and heterogeneous catalysis, mainly used in the reaction of gases and some small organic molecules, such as ORR, OER, HER, and the oxidation of small organic molecules. There are some complex and multiple reactions that do not work well together about SACs. In addition, it is less in practical applications. Reducing the size of platinum to atomic level can alleviate the shortage of platinum resources by improving the utilization rate of platinum. Nowadays, the environmental friendly, high efficient and generally known electrocatalysis devices are Zn-air batteries and H2-O2 fuel cells. The designed electrocatalysts are important materials to accelerate the electron transfer between active sites and intermediates. Electrocatalytic activity mainly depends on the electrical conductivity of the material, the number of active sites and the configuration state of the atoms. Besides, the modulation of catalysts would make the reaction towards an ideal direction. The catalytic activity can be effectively adjusted by adjusting the electronic structure of metal active sites and the electron transfer rate between metal atoms and supports. The types of metal active sites and supports should be fully developed. More control measures of electronic structure and coordination environment should be taken to ensure the interaction between active sites and intermediates. Owing to 100% atom utilization efficiency, SACs are facilitating to modulate the atom structure and show superior catalytic ability in fuel cells and Zn-air batteries. Besides, the strong interaction between single atoms and carbon skeletons makes the SACs stable at the process of reaction. These factors are beneficial to design the high performance of proper transfer between active sites and intermediates on carbon-based SACs. 7 Conclusions and prospects Owing to the high atom utilization and excellent catalytic efficiency, SACs have become mainstream catalysts and are being applied in various catalytic reactions. However, the sluggish kinetics observed in ORR and OER hinder the large-scale application of clean energy. Carbon-based SACs have been widely studied in the field of electrochemical catalysis and have shown excellent activity and stability for ORR, OER, HER and HOR have been obtained. This review discusses the environmentally friendly and highly conductive catalytically active carbon catalysts, which are considered promising supports achieving large-scale application. The modulation of active sites and carbon supports is elaborated to design highly active carbon-based SACs. Defects and coordination design of active sites and carbon skeletons are attracting increasing attention due to their important role in the rational design of SACs and the mechanism research. The different types, modulation, and characterization of active sites and carbon supports in the latest literature are introduced, providing readers with theoretical guidance. The detailed preparation of prevalent nanocarbon-based and biomass-based SACs is then elaborated to establish a strong connection between theory and practice. In the final part, the electrochemical applications of O2 and H2-related in Zn-air batteries and fuel cells are presented. To sum up, carbon-based SACs have a bright future in field of electrocatalysis due to their easy adjustability, observability, ultrahigh intrinsic activity, and increasing selectivity on the substrate and product, similar to enzymes. At first, we discuss the components of the catalyst, which consist of active sites and carbon supports. Next, the different types and modulation strategies from active sites to carbon supports are summarized. For active sites, the contents mainly consist of single/double metal active sites and coordination environment, strain, and metal-support interactions of metal atom sites. The other modulated strategies are also expected to improve the activity of SACs. However, the distance between modulated strategies and applications is obvious. Thus, the designed strategies should be circumstantial and practical to reach operability. For carbon skeletons, hollow, core-shell and hierarchical porous structures with stereochemical structures designed by researchers have anchored more metal atoms and stabilized single atoms. These structures solve the problem that the carbon supports load few atoms. Besides, the formation mechanism of common defect types on carbon supports is concluded in order to load abundant atoms. During the process of reaction, defective carbon supports are easier to corrode by acid electrode. Both constructing stable structures and improving their activity are vitally needed for excellent carbon support. Additionally, the preparation strategies of integrated and non-integrated carbon-based SACs are summarized according to different dimensions. The common preparation strategies of every dimension are the direct guidance to design various carbon-based SACs. The characterizations of the active sites and carbon supports from electron microscopy to spectrum are conducted. The existence of single atoms is confirmed by the AC-HAADT-STEM and XAS, and its coordination environment is illustrated through XPS and XAS (XANES and EXAFS). Defects on carbon supports can be tested with Raman spectroscopy, BET and TEM. Advanced in situ/ operando XANES, Raman spectroscopy, IR and MS are needed to explain the real reaction process of active sites and catalytic reaction. The catalytic mechanism of defective catalysts and coordination modulation catalysts are validated through DFT calculations. Finally, the recent electro-catalysis application of high-performance SACs is listed partly and shows the effectiveness of these regulatory strategies for Single atom catalysts. Overall, this review evaluates the species of active sites and carbon supports, how to modulate them, and how to synthesize the integrate SACs, and the effect of these modulation strategies on morphology, mechanism and performance. For the studied examples, all these modulation strategies make a contribution to Single atom catalysts and have enormous potential for large-scale industrial production in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis field. Furthermore, there is a long pathway to make a breakthrough in new sights or new techniques. The direction of strive is introduced in Fig. 27 . The Single atom catalysts are hopefully developed following the below directions. i. Enhancement of the activity of SACs In recent years, most non-noble metal SACs have performed higher activity than commercial noble metal catalysts. However, SACs are still in the initial development stage. The modulation of coordination environment, the construction of defects, and other strategies have been explored to promote activity. However, the reaction process of the catalyst is still not well understand. The modulation strategies and performance relationship are not known to design highly active catalysts. Thus, the evaluation of ORR process still remains a challenge. Inspired by advancement in robotics, the structure, components and performance of SACs can be predicted to provide guidance for catalyst synthesis. Additionally, advanced characterization techniques can be used to establish structure-performance relationships and study the catalytic mechanism of enhanced activity. With these efforts, innovative and mature theories can be developed to design SACs and the catalytic activity is improved to meet the practical applications of SACs. In the future, the design and development of carbon enzymes will be possible by significantly improving the intrinsic activity and specific selectivity of carbon-based SAC catalysts. ii. Construction of the multi-metal sites Dual-metal Single atom catalysts have a later development later than Single atom catalysts. Dual-metal Single atom catalysts have the promise of increasing the atom loading, modulating the interaction between atoms and applying for wider reactions. Thus, dual-metal atom sites exhibit higher activity than Single atom sites. At present, the formation of dual-metal atom sites still faces these questions: the ratio of metal atoms, the formation of metal bonds and so on. According to these questions, the accurate regulation of distance between two metal atoms should be considered in future development. Polynary metals like high-entropy alloys are expected to promote electric conductivity and possess synergistic effects. Multi-metal Single atom catalysts will definitely create great potential in electrocatalysis field in the near future, and play a greater role in achieving possibility of diversified catalysts, such as carbon enzymes. iii. Improvement the loading amounts of active sites Owing to the high utilization of single atoms, SACs convey superior catalytic activity surpassing nanoparticle catalysts. However, the loading of SACs is commonly lower than nanoparticle-based catalysts. Single atoms have high surface energy and provide energy to reactants. Unfortunately, SACs lead to aggregation during the preparation process. Meanwhile, the low loading is relevant to the small contact surface between atoms and carbon supports. To overcome these issues, designing the appropriate coordination environment of active sites or constructing defective carbon skeletons is beneficial to stabilize isolated atoms. More importantly, the interaction between active sites and carbon supports is a novel angle to practically modulate. Some 3D or other carbon substrates have promise in increasing the loading of active sites. The critical point between the maximum active-site density and the formation of metal aggregates is still difficult to reach. With the progress of research, the loading amount of active sites is believed to reach the ideal value. iv. Enhancement of the stability of SACs Stability includes operation stability and storage stability. The question of operation stability of carbon-based SACs is the aggregation of single atoms because of the high surface free energy and the oxidation of active sites of carbon edge in the process of reaction. The questions lead to a decrease in performance. Researchers have taken measures to modulate the distance between coordination atoms and active sites thus changing the sorts and species of carbon supports to stabilize single atom. Storage stability faces problems with the decrease of catalytic activity after a few days of standing. Surface modification of catalysts has been done to solve this problem. However, there are still gaps in balancing the improvement of oxidation resistance and the reduction of active sites. The future direction of catalysts should balance this relationship. For example, the theoretical simulation of catalysts can be firstly designed to choose the optimal model. Besides, selecting highly ordered carbon supports anchored in tightly packed active sites has the ability to form stably efficient catalysts. v. Advanced Operando or in situ characterization To accurately recognize the morphology and electronic structure of atomic sites, some advanced characterization techniques such as HAADF-STEM, XAS, and XPS are necessary. Nevertheless, these techniques have some problems in revealing the original reaction process and reaction mechanism. Such as the coordination of MN and MC is hard to differentiate (local environment), and thus the high-resolution electron microscopy is vital to be explored to distinguish the light elements and heavy metals. In situ/operando XANES, FI, and Raman spectroscopy can solve above questions, however, these techniques are not still studied very thoroughly and expensively. The detailed atomic coordination electron structure and distribution are further demonstrated through Bader charge analysis and d-band center. More advanced methodologies should be used to simulate the atomic electron structure. The DFT calculations are not suitable for the selection of catalyst theoretical simulations. Innovatively, the first-principles high-throughput screening manner (FPHTSM) has the ability to provide valuable information for designing SACs efficiently. With the development of these techniques, the structure-performance-process relationships of catalysts have the promise to be clearly elucidated. vi. Broader source range of carbon supports At present, the widely used carbon supports include CNT, graphene and MOF. The high surface area, high conductivity and rough controllable surface of carbon supports are suitable to anchor single atom. The future application still demands to explore other carbon supports towards practical application and highly efficient catalysts. For example, some biomass carbon materials from wood, straw and fruit peels have the potential to become the high-value catalysts. Some carbon skeletons with angstrom level cavities are explored to synthesize SACs. Other non-metal supports for example h-BN and g-C3N4 are considered to effectively load metal atoms. Therefore, with the exploration of novel carbon supports, the large-scale production of catalysts can be achieved and used for various fields. Shuqi Li is currently a master student under the supervision of Professor Yanyan Liu in the College of Science, Henan Agricultural University. Her research direction is the electrocatalytic reactions for energy storage and conversion. Her current work focuses on the rational design and surface regulation of biomass-derived carbon-based catalysts and the improvement of catalytic performances in reversible oxygen conversion. Yanyan Liu is currently a Professor of Science at Henan Agricultural University. In recent years, she has focused her research on the microstructure of wooden activated carbon, developing highly active and highly selective catalysts for oxygen conversion and hydrogen production by hydrolysis of borohydrogen compounds. She has published more than 100 papers and authorized more than 10 invention patents. Her work provides valuable theoretical and technical support for the large-scale preparation of highly efficient carbon catalysts, promoting the high-value utilization of forest resources. Jianchun Jiang is an expert in the field of chemical processing of forest products. He works as a professor for the Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, Chinese Academy of Forestry. He has been elected as academician of the Chinese Academy of Engineering in 2017. Since the 1980s, he has devoted himself to the basic theory and application research of biomass thermochemical conversion technology. His research focuses on revealing composition regulation in biomass pyrolysis process and the evolution law of carbide microstructure. He has published more than 300 papers and authorized more than 70 invention patents. He has obtained 4 items of the National Prize for Progress in Science and Technology.

coredata.dc:description: Single atom catalysts (SACs) possessing regulated electronic structure, high atom utilization, and superior catalytic efficiency have been studied in almost all fields in recent years. Carbon-based supporting SACs are becoming popular materials because of their low cost, high electron conductivity, and controllable surface property. At the stage of catalysts preparation, the rational design of active sites is necessary for the substantial improvement of activity of catalysts. To date, the reported design strategies are mainly about synthesis mechanism and synthetic method. The level of understanding of design strategies of carbon-based single atom catalysts is requiring deep to be paved. The design strategies about manufacturing defects and coordination modulation of catalysts are presented. The design strategies are easy to carry out in the process of drawing up preparation routes. The components of carbon-based SACs can be divided into two parts: active site and carbon skeleton. In this review, the manufacture of defects and coordination modulation of two parts are introduced, respectively. The structure features and design strategies from the active sites and carbon skeletons to the overall catalysts are deeply discussed. Then, the structural design of different nano-carbon SACs is introduced systematically. The characterization of active site and carbon skeleton and the detailed mechanism of reaction process are summarized and analyzed. Next, the applications in the field of electrocatalysis for oxygen conversion and hydrogen conversion are illustrated. The relationships between the superior performance and the structure of active sites or carbon skeletons are discussed. Finally, the conclusion of this review and prospects on the abundant space for further promotion in broader fields are depicted. This review highlights the design and preparation thoughts from the parts to the whole. The detailed and systematic discussion will provide useful guidance for design of SACs for readers.
